{{Cleanup-rewrite|date=September 2009}} {{Citations missing|date=August 2008}} {{Infobox company | name = Puzzy Power | logo = | type = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = [[1997]] | founder = [[Lene Børglum]] | defunct = | location_city = | location_country = [[Denmark]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = [[Pornography]] | products = [[Pornographic films]] | services = | market cap = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = [[Zentropa (film company)|Zentropa]] | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Puzzy Power''' (aka '''HotMale''') is a Danish film company started in 1997 as a subsidiary to [[Lars von Trier]]'s company [[Zentropa (film company)|Zentropa]], with the goal of producing [[hardcore pornography|hardcore]] [[pornographic film]]s for women. It is the only time ever a mainstream film company has openly produced hardcore porno films<ref>AVN Europe, November 2007, page 13</ref>.
The initiative was taken by producer [[Lene Børglum]], who as leader of Puzzy Power gathered a group of women (sexologist [[Gerd Winther]], editor [[Lili Henriksen]], porn model and journalist [[Christina Lohse]], line-producer [[Vibeke Windeløv]] and production assistant [[Mette Nelund]]) and developed a so-called "Statement on women and sensuality", later called The Puzzy Power Manifesto. The manifesto was shaped as a guide for the production of erotic films for women.
== Filmography == === ''Constance'' === The first film produced by Puzzy Power was ''[[Constance (1998 film)|Constance]]'' (1998), directed by [[Knud Vesterskov]] with [[Katja K]]ean, [[Anaïs]] and [[Mark Duran]] in the leading roles. It tells the story of a young woman, Constance, who arrives at the experienced Lola's house, where she is initiated into the mysteries of sexuality. The story is told in flashback via a framing devise with lyrical diary excerpts and naration read by mainstream actresses [[Christiane Bjørg Nielsen]] and [[Hella Joof]].
=== ''Pink Prison'' === The second film was ''Pink Prison'' (1999), directed by [[Lisbeth Lynghøft]] with [[Katja K]]ean and [[Mr. Marcus]] in the leads. It's about the photo journalist Mila, who infiltrates a men's penitentiary in hope of obtaining an exclusive interview with the prison warden. The film, which culminates in a lesbian scene with religious subtext, was filmed in the prison set from [[Lars von Trier]]s film ''[[Dancer in the Dark]]'' (2000).
Both ''Constance'' and ''Pink Prison'' received international attention and became the best selling sex videos in Scandinavia. In 2001, ''Constance'' was nominated for three [[AVN Award]]s for Best Art Direction, Best Music and Best Videography. In 2003, ''Pink Prison'' won a [[Venus Award]] as Best Scandinavian Film. On March 12 2006 pornography was legalized in Norway, following a case which involved a positive qualitative appraisal of ''Constance'' and ''Pink Prison''.[http://medietilsynet.no/om/nyhetsarkiv/filmklagenemnda0906]
=== ''HotMen CoolBoyz'' === The third film was the gay feature ''HotMen CoolBoyz'' (2000), directed by [[Knud Vesterskov]] and starring [[Ron Athey]] and [[Billy Herrington]]. In this connection, the Puzzy Power company called itself HotMale. The film was no financial success, but was nominated for five [[GayVN Award]]s, including Best Foreign Film.
== Restructuring == At the start of 2001, Zentropa's CEO [[Peter Aalbæk Jensen]] announced his intention to close Puzzy Power, which he claimed had been a financial disappointment. Both ''Constance'' and ''Pink Prison'' were however still ranking high on international sales lists, and soon after ''HotMen CoolBoyz'' was released as an international deluxe DVD-edition. Puzzy Power was not closed, but continued administrating the distribution and income of its three feature productions.
The task of producing new sex films for Zentropa went to a new subsidiary (later independent) company, [[Innocent Pictures]]. The two first productions from [[Innocent Pictures]] were the educational DVD ''[[Femi-X and Beyond]]'' (2004), directed by [[Nicolas Barbano]] with [[Joan Ørting]] as host, and the feature film ''[[All About Anna]]'' (2005), directed by [[Jessica Nilsson]] and starring [[Gry Bay]] and [[Mark Stevens]]. In spite of a difficult production, ''All About Anna'' became an even bigger success than both ''Constance'' and ''Pink Prison''.
The full story of Puzzy Power and [[Innocent Pictures]] is told in [[Thomas Vilhelm]]'s book ''Filmbyen'' (Ekstra Bladets Forlag, 2007).
== Sources == *[http://imdb.com/company/co0078722/ Puzzy Power] at [[IMDb]] *[http://imdb.com/company/co0075537/ HotMale] at [[IMDb]] *[http://www.innocentpictures.com Innocent Pictures official site] *[http://www.constance.dk ''Constance'' official site] *[http://www.pinkprison.dk ''Pink Prison'' official site] *[http://www.hotmencoolboyz.dk ''HotMen CoolBoyz'' official site] *[http://www.innocentpictures.com/constance_en_manifest.htm The Puzzy Power Manifesto] *[http://medietilsynet.no/om/nyhetsarkiv/filmklagenemnda0906 Norwegian Media Authority none-censorship decision]

:''Stalags redirects here. For the POW camps, see [[Stalag]]. For the documentary about Stalag fiction, see [[Stalags (film)]]'' [[Image:Ma 416Stalag.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The front and back cover of ''Stalag 13'', an example of Stalag literature, shows the sexualization of female SS guards characteristic of the genre.]] '''Stalag fiction''' was a short-lived genre of [[Israeli literature|Israeli fiction]] [[Nazi exploitation]] that flourished in the early 1960s, at the time of the [[Adolf Eichmann|Eichmann trial]].
==Premise== Purported to be translations of English-language books by prisoners in [[concentration camp]]s, these books were highly [[pornography|pornographic]] accounts of imprisonment, generally of Allied soldiers, sexual [[Sado-masochism|brutalization]] by female [[SS]] guards, and the prisoners' eventual revenge, which usually consisted of the [[rape]] and [[murder]] of their tormentors.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Entertainment/2007/09/06/documentary_looks_at_nazi_porn_in_israel/5000/| title=Documentary looks at Nazi porn in Israel| work=[[UPI]] | date=2007-09-06}}</ref> The books, with titles like ''I Was Colonel Schultz's Private Bitch'', were especially popular among adolescent boys, often the children of concentration camp survivors.
==History== The books emerged from the culture of silence that surrounded the [[Holocaust]], especially in [[Israel]], until the Eichmann trial. Many young people lived in the shadow of these events, but could find no answers to their inevitable questions, whether from their parents or their teachers. For most of adolescents, the only answers they could find were in the book ''[[The House of Dolls]]'' ([[1955 in literature|1955]]) by [[Yehiel De-Nur|K. Tzetnik]], a then-anonymous survivor of [[Auschwitz]] who wrote about women prisoners forced into prostitution by the [[Nazi]] guards—his book was later alleged to be a work of fiction. Nevertheless, it had an impact on young Israeli males as they went through puberty: questions of identity and their parents' violent past melted into their emerging sexual identity, often fostering graphic S&M fantasies.{{Fact|date=March 2009}} This became more prevalent during the highly publicized Eichmann trial, when these same young people were exposed to detailed descriptions of the concentration and death camps for the very first time. K. Tzetnik himself was one of the witnesses who provided graphic testimony during the trial.
Exploiting these trends, a group of Israeli publishers began to publish [[dime novel]]-format memoirs, describing abuse, particularly sexual abuse, in the concentration camps. Sold in magazine kiosks, the novels, ostensibly first-person memoirs, became best-sellers. According to filmmaker [[Ari Libsker]], "the Holocaust pictures that I saw, as one who grew up here, were of naked women."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.cinephil.co.il/_Uploads/416NY_Times_Stalags.pdf| title=Israel's Unexpected Spinoff| publisher=[[The New York Times]]| author=Isabel Kershner| format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]| date=2007-09-06}}</ref> These had a marked impact on an otherwise puritanical society, and the books quickly became bestsellers.
They disappeared almost as quickly as they appeared. Within two years of the appearance of the first publication, the publishers were accused by an Israeli court of distributing pornography, and the books were discontinued. Although still available underground, certain titles earned the ire of the establishment, and efforts were made to find and destroy them.
In 2007, the genre re-entered public debate in Israel after Israeli filmmaker [[Ari Libsker]] featured the books in a documentary film, ''[[Stalags (film)|Stalags]]''.<ref>[http://www.cinephil.co.il/Index.asp?CategoryID=77&ArticleID=416 cinephil.co.il]</ref>

[[File:XRCO 2009.jpg|thumb|600px|Cast and crew of the feature ''Not Bewitched'' on stage during the 25th Anniversary XRCO Awards at The Highlands, Hollywood, CA on 04/17/09. From left to right: Nina Hartley, Eva Angelina, Will Ryder (director), Flower Tucci, Sunny Lane (back to camera, in yellow dress), Jenna Haze, Teagan Presley, Scott David (producer).]] The '''XRCO Awards''' are given by the [[X-Rated Critics Organization]] annually to people working in [[adult entertainment]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bwdl.net/XRCO-2/winners.htm |title=Yearly Winners & Noms |publisher=[[X-Rated Critics Organization]] |accessdate=2008-10-17}}</ref> Some of the works and workers are inducted into the [[XRCO Hall of Fame]] during the awards.
The XRCO online archive is missing results prior to 1993. The site encourages visitors to send in older results.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bwdl.net/XRCO-2/oldies.html|title=Previous Winners and Noms - 2002 & Before|publisher=[[X-Rated Critics Organization]]|accessdate=2008-10-17}}</ref>
==History== The first XRCO Awards were presented in [[Hollywood]] on [[February 14]], [[1985]]. Until 1991, the awards were presented on [[Valentine's Day]] each year.

[[Image:Jlps pink.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Jesus Loves Porn Stars]] '''XXXchurch.com''' is a non-profit organization that aims to help those who struggle with [[pornography]]. Its target is consumers and those in the pornography industry. The organization, whose slogan is the "#1 Christian Porn Site", launched in January 2002 when the founders, Mike Foster and Craig Gross, set up a booth inside the [[AVN Adult Entertainment Expo]] in [[Las Vegas Strip|Las Vegas]] to promote the [[website]] as an alternative to porn. They annually attend shows worldwide.http://xxxchurch.com/07/pornpatrol/index.php The organization has received support from prominent [[Christian]] pastors such as [[Bill Hybels]] and [[Rob Bell]] and has also been deemed controversial by other Christian leaders.{{citation needed|date=November 2008}} The organization gives its vision as: "XXXchurch is the #1 Christian porn site designed to bring awareness, openness and accountability to those affected by pornography. We are an online community that tours the world speaking at colleges, churches and community centers. XXXchurch.com exists to help those who are in over their heads with pornography, both consumers and those in the industry." ==Jesus Loves Porn Stars== XXXchurch has gained national press coverage and notoriety through exhibiting at pornography conventions across the world. The group passes out [[Bible]]s with "Jesus Loves Porn Stars" on the front. They have given away thousands of Bibles at porn conventions, and this facet of their ministry has been featured in US national media.http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1191829,00.htmlhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WwLcg-mxHeQ ==Porn Debate== The founder of XXXchurch.com, Craig Gross, regularly debates with porn star [[Ron Jeremy]] in an event called "The Porn Debate"http://porndebate.com/ on college campuses across the US. In the summer of 2007, the duo embarked on a theater tour across the eastern US. In 2008, the debate was featured on ABC News' ''Nightline'' both on air and online, with the segment becoming the most watched in Nightline's online viewing history.http://www.abcnews.go.com/Nightline/FaceOff/ ==X3Watch== XXXchurch.com also offers [[accountability software]] called [http://x3watch.com X3Watch]. The software logs all questionable websites that a user accesses based on content type and then sends a report to an "accountability partner" of the person's choosing. The program is free to download without tech support but a premium version is offered that includes support for a small donation.http://X3watch.com The software can be turned off at any time. An uninstall or turn off of the software is logged in the email reports. The goal of the software is for individuals to be open, honest and accountable to each other with their web surfing. ==XXXchurch.tv== In 2008 the organization launched a video podcast that documents the current campaigns of XXXchurch. It is released every two weeks on XXXchurch.tv and [[iTunes]].http://xxxchurch.tv ==Radio== XXXcurch has several radio public service announcements airing across the US and abroad on various radio staions and syndicated programs such as [[RadioU]]http://www.tvulive.com/radiou/riot2.htm RadioU, The Full Armor Of God Broadcasthttp://www.fullarmorradio.com/home The Full Armor Of God Broadcast, [[Refuge Radio]]http://www.refugeradio.com/Events/details.cfm?ID=867 Refuge Radio, [[Malone University]] Radiohttp://www.malone.edu/1446 Malone University Radio and Fuel Radiohttp://www.fuelradio.fm/index.php Fuel Radio ==In Popular Culture== XXXchurch.com has been featured in Time, Playboy, GQ, The Today Show, CNN [http://edition.cnn.com/2007/US/04/04/porn.addiction/index.html 'Porn & Pancakes' fights X-rated addictions - CNN.com], Good Morning America, CBS Evening News, Anderson Cooper 360, LA Times, New York Times and ABC News Nightline. http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/Beliefs/story?id=2841065 The "Porn and Pancakes" event was mentioned on the February 3, 2007 episode of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' during the ''[[Weekend Update]]''.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G0JiVA33huw The origins of XXXchurch were documented in a film called ''Missionary Positions''.http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=6125906980763324273&q=missionary+positions The popular [[Internet meme]] "[[Every time you masturbate... God kills a kitten]]" was used by XXXchurch.com's "Operation: Save the Kittens", which used the video to talk about [[masturbation]].http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xocPtKaRcD8 Craig Gross appeared on an episode of [[MTV|MTV's]] [[True Life]], In which he counseled a man addicted to porn. ==Craig Gross== Craig Gross, one of the founders and the leader of the XXXchurch as of 2008, is an international speaker and author.{{citation needed|date=September 2009}} He has authored ''Questions You Can’t Ask Your Mama About Sex'', ''The Gutter'', ''Dirty Little Secret'' and ''Starving Jesus''.http://craiggross.com ==References== ==External links== * [http://xxxchurch.com Official site] * [http://www.myspace.com/xxxchurch XXXchurch's Official MySpace] * [http://apps.facebook.com/causes/1316 XXXchurch's Facebook Page] * [http://www.x3watch.com X3watch accountability software] * [http://www.CraigGross.com Craig Gross' Website] {{refend}} [[Category:Accountability software]] [[Category:Christian websites]] [[Category:Pornography]] [[Category:Sexuality in Christianity]]

The '''Erotic Awards''' is an annual British event that honours achievement in [[erotica]] worldwide.<ref name="timeout">{{cite web | title =Night of the Senses and Erotic Awards 2008| publisher =''Timeout''| url = http://www.timeout.com/london/alternative-nightlife/events/807251/night_of_the_senses_and_erotic_awards_2008.html| date = 2008-09-12| accessdate = 2008-09-25}}</ref>
Founded in 1994 by sexuality campaigner [[Tuppy Owens]], the awards were first called the Erotic Oscars, until the name had to be changed.<ref name="eroz">{{cite web | title =The UK Erotic Awards| publisher =Eros Zine | url = http://www.eros-ny.com/articles/2002-11-12/flyingdick/| date = 2002-12-11| accessdate = 2008-09-25}}</ref> The awards ceremony are held during the Night of the Senses, an annual event in London that was originally known as the Sex Maniacs Ball.<ref name="xbiz">{{cite web | title =U.K. Erotic Awards Honors Sexuality | publisher =XBiz.com | url = http://www.xbiz.com/news/news_piece.php?id=16919&mi=all&q=javors| date = 2006-08-30| accessdate = 2008-09-25}}</ref><ref name="erotic">{{cite web | title = About Us| publisher = The Erotic Awards| url =http://www.erotic-awards.co.uk/about.shtml | accessdate =2008-09-25 }}</ref> The Leydig Trust organises the awards to raise funds for Outsiders, a charity that helps disabled people to find partners.<ref name="eroz"/>
The 21 award categories include Campaigner, Sex Worker, Striptease Artist, Fashion, Academic, Writer, and Film.<ref name="eroticcat">{{cite web | title = 2008 Finalists| publisher = The Erotic Awards| url =http://www.erotic-awards.co.uk/finalists.shtml | accessdate =2008-09-25 }}</ref> Nominations come from the public, via the Erotic Awards website or by brochure, and three finalists in each category are then selected by a jury.<ref name="eroz"/> The winners are announced during the Night of the Senses, where the finalists' work is also exhibited and performed.<ref name="erotic"/>
Past winners have included film director [[Derek Jarman]], American pornstar [[Annie Sprinkle]], the Australian website [[abbywinters.com]], and human rights activist [[Peter Tatchell]].<ref name="erotic"/>

{{Infobox_Scientist | name = Berl Kutchinsky | image = Berl Kutchinsky.JPG | image_width = 200px | caption = Berl Kutchinsky | birth_date = {{birth date|1935|8|14}} | birth_place = [[Aarhus]], [[Denmark]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1995|3|9|1935|8|14}} | death_place = [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] | nationality = [[Denmark|Danish]] | field = [[Criminology]] | work_institutions = [[University of Copenhagen]] | known_for = [[Public health effects of pornography]] }}
'''Berl Kutchinsky''' (1935 - 1995) was a [[Denmark|Danish]] Professor of [[Criminology]] at the [[University of Copenhagen]].<ref name=age/><ref name=bocaraton>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Europe debates control of child porn import |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zNgPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kI0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6807,3748188&dq=berl-kutchinsky |work=[[Boca Raton News]] |publisher= |page=6|date=1984-09-16 |accessdate=2009-06-16}}</ref> He became internationally famous for his studies in the [[public health effects of pornography]].
He was based in Denmark, which in 1969 became the first country to legalize [[hardcore pornography]]<ref name=age>{{cite web |url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/09/19/1063625202157.html |title=X-rated? Outdated |accessdate=2009-06-16 |author=Helen Vnuk |date=2003-09-20 |work=[[The Age]] |publisher=}}</ref><ref>Berl Kutchinsky: [http://www.fanny-hill.net/html/o1a_danish_pornography_laws.htm The first law that legalized pornography]</ref> Sweden followed suit in 1970, and West Germany in 1973.<ref name=age/> Kutchinsky was therefore in a unique position to study the effect of pornography on a massive scale. Over the next two decades Kutchinsky carried out extensive research into crime statistics in the three countries.<ref name=age/> His findings were that increased availability of pornography had not led to an increase in [[sexual violence]].<ref name=age/> He found that the incidence of certain sex crimes had in fact fallen, including rates of [[child sexual abuse]] in Denmark.<ref name=age/>
His first work on the subject, ''Studies on Pornography and sex crimes in Denmark'' (1970), was a scientific report ordered by the United States' [[President's Commission on Obscenity and Pornography]]. It found that the legalizing of pornography in Denmark had not (as had been expected) resulted in an increase in sex crimes.<ref>[http://home20.inet.tele.dk/gorzelak/dps/anmeldelser/barbano_kutchinsky.html Berl Kutchinsky: ''Studies on Pornography and sex crimes in Denmark'']</ref>
In 1980 he helped to draft the law which banned [[child pornography]] in Denmark; after which according to him, "Child porn has largely disappeared from Denmark."<ref name=bocaraton/> Berl Kutchinsky's last book, ''Law, pornography, and crime: The Danish experience'', was edited by his colleague Annika Snare and published posthumously in 1999.
==Selected works== *''Studies on Pornography and sex crimes in Denmark'' (New Social Science Monographs, Denmark 1970) *''Obscenity and Pornography: Behavioral Aspects'', In: ''Encyclopedia of Crime and Justice'', Vol. 3, pp 1077–1086 (The Free Press, Macmillan, New York 1983) *''Pornography and its Effects in Denmark and the United States: A Rejoinder and Beyond'', in: ''Comparative Social Research'', vol. 8, pp. 301-30 (JAI Press, USA 1985) *''Som hånd i hanke'', In: ''Hug'' nr. 42/43 (Tiderne Skifter, Denmark 1985) *''Big sister is watching!'', In: ''Umoralske opstød - 15 debatindlæg om s/m, pornografi og nypuritanisme'' (Juvelen, Denmark 1986) *''Legalised pornography in Denmark'', In: ''Men Confronting Pornography'', pp. 233-45, 335-6 (Crown Publishers, New York 1990) *''Pornography and rape: Theory and practice? Evidence from crime data in four countries where pornography is easily available'', In: ''International Journal of Law and Psychiatry'', vol. 14, 1991, no. 1 & 2, pp. 47-64. (1991) *[http://www.aic.gov.au/publications/proceedings/14/kutchinsky.pdf ''Pornography, Sex Crime and Public Policy''] (Institute of Criminology and Criminal Science, University of Copenhagen, Denmark 1991) *''Den pornografiske scene'', In: ''Social Kritik'' nr. 64, June 1999 (Selskabet til fremme af Social Debat, Denmark 1999) *''Law, pornography, and crime: The Danish experience'' (Pax Forlag, Oslo 1999)
==Further reading== *Annika Snare: ''Pornoliberaliseringens mange facetter'', In: ''Social Kritik'' nr. 64, June 1999 (Selskabet til fremme af Social Debat, Denmark 1999) *[http://home20.inet.tele.dk/gorzelak/dps/anmeldelser/barbano_kutchinsky.html A Danish-language article about Berl Kutchinsky's ''Studies on Pornography and sex crimes in Denmark'']

{{Male adult bio | name = Roger T. Pipe | image = [[Image:Trinity and Roger T. Pipe.jpg|200px]] | caption = Roger T. Pipe (right), with pornographic actress Trinity, at the [[AVN Adult Entertainment Expo]], 2000. | birth = {{birth date and age|1967|10|17}} | location = [[California]], [[United States]] | birthname = <!-- Do not add unless you have a RELIABLE SOURCE!! --> | spouse = | death = | height = {{height|ft=6|in=1}} | weight = {{convert|195|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | shoe size = | eye color = Blue | hair color = Brown | skin color = White | blood = | orientation = Straight | ethnicity = Caucasian | alias = Rog T. Pipe | homepage = http://www.rogreviews.com }}
'''Roger T. Pipe''' (born October 1967) is the pseudonym of an [[United States|American]] pornographic film critic, adult radio commentator and occasional writer and director <ref name=rog1>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogreviews.com/interviews/Daisy_Chain2.asp|title=Interview with Daisy Chain|author=Rog T. Pipe|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref> residing in [[California]]. Pipe operates a website, [http://www.rogreviews.com RogReviews] which sports reviews of movies, sex toys and websites involving the adult entertainment industry, as well as audio and text interviews with stars, directors and other important figureheads. He is an active member of the [[X-Rated Critics Organization]].<ref name=XRCO>[http://www.bwdl.net/XRCO-2/xrcomembers.htm "Current XRCO Members"], [[XRCO]] official site. Retrieved [[2008-01-04]].</ref>
== Biography == === Personal life === Pipe was born in October 1967 <ref name=adultfilmfan>{{cite web|url=http://adultfilmfan.com/rogerpipe/rogerpipeinterview.php|title=Interview with Rog T. Pipe|author=Cousin Stevie|publisher=adultfilmfan.com}}</ref> and grew up in [[San Marcos, California|San Marcos]] <ref name=rog2>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogreviews.com/interviews/Shay_Jordan.asp|title=Interview with Shay Jordan|author=Rog T. Pipe|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref> in southern California. He went to [[Cal-State Fullerton]] and graduated with a degree in Communications <ref name=MySpace>{{cite web|url=http://www.myspace.com/rogtpipe|title=Rog T. Pipe's MySpace Home Page|author=Rog T. Pipe|publisher=myspace.com}}</ref>.
Pipe is currently married, and has been for 15 years. His wife is consistently referred to only as “Mrs. Rog,” <ref name=rog3>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogreviews.com/news/read_article.asp?sku=4069|title=Happy 15th Anniversary Mrs. Rog!|author=Rog T. Pipe|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref> who is supportive of his career <ref name=serenity>{{cite web|url=http://www.theworldofgoddess.com/rogerpipeinter.htm|title=Interview with Rog T. Pipe|author=Serenity|publisher=theworldofthegoddess.com}}</ref>. He has confirmed that he has children, but their names and ages have not been revealed. He has also stated that Mrs. Rog does occasionally join him in watching porn, though not nearly as often as he would like. <ref name="adultfilmfan"/>
=== Career === Pipe began watching pornography consistently starting in 1985. <ref name="adultfilmfan"/> It wasn’t until 1995, while doing a search on the internet for a rare porn title, that he stumbled across a website where individuals were discussing and reviewing pornographic titles. After several days, Pipe decided that he would try his own luck by reviewing movies from his private collection, writing “from the heart of a porn fan.” <ref name="adultfilmfan"/> The response was seemingly overnight, and soon, Pipe’s reviews were being included on distributor websites to establish a more personal connection with those buying the videos.
Eventually, Pipe launched [http://www.rogreviews.com Rog Reviews] in 1998, intending only to showcase his reviews, a decision made partially in retaliation against the [[Adult Video News Awards]], for which he had briefly worked for. The experience left Pipe jaded against the more mainstream avenues, but has since worked out to be “very beneficial.” Pipe has said in interviews that the same individual who dismissed him ([[Mark Kulkis]]) has ensured Pipe’s accessibility to every major adult film premiere for the companies he represents, suggesting that while they way in which they parted was not ideal, there still held an attraction to his ability to write. <ref name="serenity"/>
During the early years of the site’s launch, Pipe also had a day job as a warehouse and office manager for a local software company. <ref name="serenity"/> At this time, Pipe also worked on several amateur scripts, the most hugely popular being “Guilty Pleasures,” which Pipe failed to receive credit for in the final cut. <ref name=rog4>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogreviews.com/reviews/read_review.asp?sku=899|title=Review of Guilty Pleasures|author=Rog T. Pipe|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref> By 2002, Pipe began including sex toy and website reviews, enticing outside free-lance reviewers to contribute, the most prolific of which is midwestern college co-ed Savana Switzer.
In 2005, Pipe joined [[The Daily Noise]], an uncensored entertainment radio talk show broadcast out of [[Las Vegas metropolitan area|Las Vegas]], hosted by spin jocks Kaan Soler and Jimmy Diggs, as a weekly guest commentator. The Daily Noise folded in late August 2007, signaling the end of a successful three-year run. Prior to the Daily Noise, Pipe also had a number of appearances on the radio show “Lovebytes,” hosted by [[Dr. Bob Berkowitz]] on Eyada.com, and had been in the process of negotiating a deal for his own news show when Eyada went off the air. <ref name=serenity>{{cite web|url=>[http://www.theworldofgoddess.com/rogerpipeinter.htm|title=Interview with Rog T. Pipe|author=Serenity|publisher=theworldofthegoddess.com}}]</ref>
Earlier this year, Pipe introduced interviews with industry members through podcasts, a decision which has increased his site’s exposure considerably. In addition to the podcasts, his site also offers textual transcripts of the interviews, galleries of industry giants and amateur fans, and a wide selection of reviews of websites and sex toys.
==== Views on the Industry ==== Despite being at the heart of the industry, Pipe grapples with the implications of porn in regards to the long-term effects it can have on its stars, urging aspiring actors and actresses to be absolutely sure they want to get involved in adult entertainment <ref name=rog5>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogreviews.com/news/read_article.asp?sku=4118|title=Savana Switzer's Five-Question Interview with Rog T. Pipe|author=Savana Switzer|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref>. However, Pipe maintains he is one of the most open-minded in the business, believing that “all women, in all shapes, sizes and ages should be appreciated by the men who appreciate them. As far as perfect sizes, I’m the wrong guy to ask. My idea of perfect varies from woman to woman…I find beauty in just about every shape and size.” <ref name="serenity"/>
Pipe has also voiced his frustration about the treatment of women within the industry, criticizing many as being hurt by the “Jackassization,” (a term referring to the [[MTV]] show, "[[Jackass (TV series)|Jackass]]," which popularizes a group of individuals performing dangerous—and arguably, degrading—stunts for laughs and shock effect) of many of the industry’s most popular films. <ref name=rog6>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogreviews.com/reviews/read_review.asp?sku=4108|title=Review of the Movie Down the Hatch 19|author=Rog T. Pipe|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref>
Following the outbreak of [[HIV]] among five actors (beginning with [[Darren James]]) in the spring of 2004, Pipe expressed his disappointment that the advent of the Internet had opened up the door for anyone to shoot, which can exclude those involved from being in safe, professional environments and circumstances. <ref name="adultfilmfan"/>. He did, however, commend the industry for avoiding replicating the mistakes of the previous outbreak in 1999 (where [[Tricia Devereaux]] and [[Brooke Ashley]] were blamed for “venturing outside the industry” until it was revealed that the infected "Patient X" was actually star [[Mark Wallice]] <ref name="adultfilmfan"/>) and for companies such as Platinum X covering the cost to continually test their talent.
==== Professional Relationships and Disputes ==== Pipe admits to sustaining several “professional crushes,” the most publicized of which has been contemporary starlet [[Aurora Snow]]. <ref name=rog7>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogreviews.com/interviews/aurora_snow3.asp|title=Interview with Aurora Snow|author=Rog T. Pipe|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref> More recently, he's referred to [[Shay Jordan]] as his 'next ex-Mrs. Rog' <ref name=rog2>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogreviews.com/interviews/shay_jordan_07.asp|title=Interview with Shay Jordan|author=Rog T. Pipe|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref>. He also reveres former adult superstar [[Christy Canyon]], who starred in many porn movies during the 80's, identified as his "first porn crush." He’s also expressed that his favorite stars of all-time are Kaitlyn Ashley and Tom Byron.
However, Pipe has also been at the heart of several controversies in the adult entertainment industry, including a public feud with director Skeeter Kerkove. Though the exact nature of the dispute has never been revealed, it is widely believed it resulted from Kerkove’s ex-wife, former adult actress and director [[Bridgette Kerkove]], tossing a drink in Pipe’s face. <ref name=rog9>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogreviews.com/news/read_article.asp?sku=4050|title=Anyone know a good lawyer?|author=Rog T. Pipe|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref> Although she later called Pipe and apologized for the incident, Kerkove has continued to deny Pipe’s version of events. <ref name=adultfyi>{{cite web|url=http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=23600|title=Skeeter: Roger T. Pipe Owes Otto Bauer an Apology; T. Pipe a "hang-around" says Skeeter|author=Gene Ross|publisher=adultfyi.com}}</ref>
The rivalry exploded in July of this year, when porn gossip columnist Gene Ross blogged about a conversation he had with Kerkove, who swore that Snow had told him she had slept with Pipe in a secret [[point of view pornography]] scene to get ahead in the industry and likewise contended that lesser-known actress [[Layla Jade]] had also shot a secret scene with Pipe. <ref name="adultfyi"/> Pipe responded to the allegations, stating “No such scene was ever shot. Come on....if I had shot that, everyone would know about it. I would be showing everyone on the freaking planet. That isn't the sort of thing you hide from.” <ref name=adultfyi2>{{cite web|url=http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=23589|title=Roger T. Pipe Adds Comments|author=Gene Ross|publisher=adultfyi.com}}</ref>
Although Snow and Jade have remained silent on the issue publicly, adult film star and director [[Jay Ashley]] (who also happens to be Snow’s boyfriend) defended Pipe and Snow against Kerkove’s statements, insisting that Snow has “earned everything she got,” and that the story of a secret scene between Pipe and Snow has no credibility or substance. <ref name=adultfyi3>{{cite web|url=http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=23707|title=Jay Ashley: Aurora Snow and Roger T. Pipe - No Way, Jose|author=Gene Ross|publisher=adultfyi.com}}</ref>
Kerkove attempted to further fan the flames by shooting a scene in October specifically ‘dedicated’ to Pipe. <ref name=adultfyi4>{{cite web|url=http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=23625|title=Skeeter: 'Rog T. Pipe, this bar stool's for you!'|author=Gene Ross|publisher=adultfyi.com}}</ref> The homage is in tribute to a review Pipe had written for the movie “Triple Threat,” in which he characterized two characters having sex on a barstool as coming from “a page in the [[Jules Jordan]] handbook” <ref name=rog10>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogreviews.com/reviews/read_review.asp?sku=3706|title=Review of the Movie Triple Threat|author=Rog T. Pipe|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref> . Kerkove and “Triple Threat” director [[Otto Bauer]] (during the Aurora Snow controversy) each expressed their resentment of his critique, despite the fact the review had been posted over two years earlier. <ref name="adultfyi"/>. The argument was resurrected again with another tangent directed at Pipe, but has since died down. <ref name=adultfyi5>{{cite web|url=http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=23636|title=Otto Bauer: I Hate to Sully Jules Jordan's Name Through This Moron Roger T. Pipe|author=Gene Ross|publisher=adultfyi.com}}</ref>
However, at the 2008 [[Adult Entertainment Expo]], according to Pipe's website, he and Bauer had a chance to bury the hatchet. <ref name=rog11>{{cite web|url=http://www.adultfyi.com/read.php?ID=23636|title=Rog's AEE Journal: Day 2 Nikita Denise, Savana Interviews Aurora, Teagan & Meet Otto Bauer|author=Roger T. Pipe|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref> Pipe wrote on his website:
''As some of you may recall, Otto had a few words for me on Gene’s site last summer. I didn’t comment much at the time because I’ve never met Otto and certainly have nothing against him. Since that I time I had been looking forward to a face to face. I introduced myself and asked Otto for one minute to set the record straight. He granted me that minute, listened as explained to him that some of the things he was told I said did not come from me. Otto listened to me, shook my hand and said “I don’t have a problem with anything you have said. I have a problem with things you didn’t say. So we have no problem.” We talked for a few minutes about the review in question, the way things get fucked up and agreed that from now on, we have no been and that both of us would talk to rather than about one another. I couldn’t have been happier with how things went.''
Pipe has also had some public exchanges regarding former adult film superstar, [[Asia Carrera]] <ref name="serenity"/> However, when Carrera’s husband, nutritionist and author [[Don Lemmon]], died in a car crash in June 2006, Pipe solicited his readers for financial and emotional support for the grieving Carrera <ref name=rog11>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogreviews.com/news/read_article.asp?sku=3275|title=Asia Carrera Update|author=Rog T. Pipe|publisher=rogreviews.com}}</ref> ==== Hall of Fame ==== Elected to 2009 XRCO Hall of Fame

{{Citations missing|date=January 2008}} {{Pwcompanybox |name=Naked Women's Wrestling League |image=Nwwl logo.jpg |acronym=NWWL |established=2004 |folded= |style= |location= |founder= |owner=[[Howard Mann]] |parent= |sister= |formerly= |website=www.nwwl.com |}} The '''Naked Women's Wrestling League''', also known as '''NWWL''', is [[Pornographic]] company which features naked females battling in the ring. Aside from the naked wrestling, another attraction to the show was the hostess – [[Carmen Electra]]. ==History== The show made its debut in 2004 with the release of the [[pay-per-view]] show "Vegas Stripped". It returned to pay-per-view in 2006, with the "Naked Revolution" show. This time out, Carmen Electra hosted the show, while other celebrities to appear on the program included legendary pro-wrestling manager [[Jimmy Hart|Jimmy "Mouth of the South" Hart]] as well as adult entertainment star [[Mary Carey (pornographic actress)|Mary Carey]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nwwl.com/index.php/news/nwwl-news/57-call-for-fans-opinions-on-the-mary-carey-issue.html|title=Call For Fan’s Opinions On The “Mary Carey Issue” }}. Since the show began, the NWWL wrestlers have been featured in [[Penthouse (magazine)|Penthouse]], [[Playboy]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nwwl.com/index.php/news/nwwl-news/59-nwwl-in-playboy-magazine.html|title=NWWL In Playboy Magazine}} and [[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nwwl.com/index.php/news/nwwl-news/58-nwwl-ladies-featured-in-maxmen-magazine.html|title=NWWL Ladies Featured in Maxmen Magazine }} magazines as well as on [[CBS News]] and countless radio show interviews. In 2007, Carmen Electra announced a lawsuit against the NWWL for, among other things, [[breach of contract]] and failure to pay money that she claimed was still due to her. In response, NWWL owner [[Howard Mann]] made it public that she had been paid all money due to her and that her claims were without merit. In late 2007, the NWWL launched a new website – NWWL.com – where their nude wrestling matches are available for [[download]]. As of April 2008, the league appears to be alive and well, producing new content and touring live shows in the US.{{cite web|url=http://www.cndb.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?p=44889|title=CNDB thread on NWWL}} '''''CAUTION: Nudity''''' ==Participating wrestlers==

'''The UK Adult Film and Television Awards''' (UKAFTA) is an annual awards ceremony for the UK [[adult industry]]. Redzone Pictures and the UK Adult Producers Trade Association organise the awards to promote the industry in the UK.<ref name="New">{{cite web | title = New Adult Movie Awards in England| author=Bob Preston | publisher =XBiz.com | url =http://www.xbiz.com/news/news_piece.php?id=17776&mi=all&q=tyle | date = 2006-10-24| accessdate = 2008-11-18}}</ref> The inaugural awards show was held on 17 November 2006 at the [[Hammersmith Palais]], [[London]], and was hosted by porn actor and director [[Ben Dover]].<ref name="Guardian">{{cite web | title =VIPs stay away from UK Adult Film Awards ceremony| author=Paul Lewis | publisher =''The Guardian'' | url =http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2006/nov/18/film.filmnews | date = 2006-11-18| accessdate = 2008-11-18}}</ref> There are around 30 award categories, honouring performance, production and technical achievements in film, television and the Internet. Notable award nominees include the TV series ''[[The Secret Diary of a Call Girl]]'', starring [[Billy Piper]], which was nominated for Best Softcore Production at the 2007 Awards.<ref name="piper">{{cite web | title =Piper series up for adult award | publisher =BBC News | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7103189.stm |date = 2007-11-20 | accessdate = 2008-11-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/pandora/mailer-champions-bad-sex-from-beyond-the-grave-760747.html|title=Mailer champions bad sex from beyond the grave - Pandora, People - The Independent|publisher=www.independent.co.uk| date=2007-11-28|accessdate=2009-03-07|last=Duff |first=Oliver}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/arts_entertainment/piper+drama+up+for+adult+film+award/1071447|title=Channel 4 - News - Piper drama up for adult film award|publisher=www.channel4.com|date=2007-11-20|accessdate=2009-03-09}}</ref> The 2008 Awards were held at The Troxy, London on 20 November 2008 and were hosted by the actress [[Kate Robbins]].<ref name="UKAFTA">{{cite web | title =UKAFTA Awards 2008 | publisher =UKAFTA.com | url =http://www.ukafta.com/award.php?id=2 | accessdate = 2008-11-18}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox Book | name = Naked Ambition: An R Rated Look at an X Rated Industry | image = [[Image: Naked-Ambition-cover_s.jpg|125px]] | author = [[Michael Grecco]] (photographer), [[Dave Navarro]] and [[Larry Flynt]] (forewords), [[Lonn Friend]] and Rob Hill (editors) | country = [[United States]] | language = [[English language|English]] | genre = [[Photography]]
[[Human sexuality|Sexuality]] | publisher = Rock Out Books | release_date = [[2007-11-01]] | media_type = Print ([[hardcover]]) | pages = 224 | isbn = 0979331404}} '''''Naked Ambition: An R Rated Look at an X Rated Industry''''' is the third [[portrait photography ]] book by American photographer [[Michael Grecco]]. It is published by Rock Out Books (ISBN 0979331404). The book contains over 200 photographs of actors, filmmakers and personalities in the world of [[sex industry|adult entertainment]]. Grecco photographed his subjects during the 2007 [[AVN Adult Entertainment Expo]] in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], the convention which surrounds the annual [[AVN Awards]]. The book's forewords, written by rock musician [[Dave Navarro]] and [[Hustler]] magazine editor [[Larry Flynt]], discuss modern culture's acceptance of pornography into the mainstream, which allows an overtly sexual work like this to be considered a [[coffee table book]]. Included among the portrait subjects are [[Larry Flynt]], [[Jenna Jameson]], [[Ron Jeremy]], [[Chi Chi LaRue]], [[Tera Patrick]], [[Alexandra Silk]], [[Katsuni]], [[Sunny Lane]], [[Kurt Lockwood]], and Michelle Aston. Uncommon in pornography-related works, the photographs do not seem to have been altered with any significant [[image editing]] or [[photo manipulation]], thus avoiding the layer of fantasy usually applied to actors in this field. ''Naked Ambition'' was edited by former ''RIP magazine'' editor [[Lonn Friend]] and former ''[[FHM]]'' editor Rob Hill. ==External links== *[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cA_u_70azZI Naked Ambition preview video] on YouTube.com *[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2007/11/15/violetblue.DTL&hw=naked+ambition&sn=001&sc=1000 Naked Ambition review and Michael Grecco interview] on San Francisco Chronicle website *[http://www.blackbookmag.com/features/comments/michael-greccos-naked-ambition/#When:17:31:00Z Naked Ambition book review] on BlackBook website *[http://www.citypaper.net/articles/2007/11/29/just-do-it-3 Naked Ambition book review] on Philadelphia City Paper website *[http://www.philadelphiaweekly.com/articles/15915 "A-List" announcement] on Philadelphia Weekly website *[http://www.nextmagazine.com/features/1515_3.php Feature] on Next Magazine website *[http://www.bostonnow.com/entertainment/books/2007/11/20/grecco-and-the-art-of-naked-ambition Naked Ambition book review] on Boston Now website *[http://www.doubleexposure.com/NakedAmbitionBook.shtml Naked Ambition feature] on Double Exposure website *[http://www.kusi.com/news/insidesd/10947386.html Michael Grecco video interview] on KSUI News San Diego * [http://www.nakedambition.com/ Naked Ambition] Website * [http://www.michaelgrecco.com/ Michael Grecco] Website [[Category:2007 books]] [[Category:Books of photographs]] [[Category:Pornography]]

[[image:Jenna Jameson DSC 0138.JPG|thumb|[[Jenna Jameson]] at the 2005 XBIZ Award Show]]
'''XBIZ Awards''' are given annually to honor "individuals, companies, performers and products that play an essential part in the growth and success of [[adult entertainment]]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.xbizawards.com/theshow.php |title=XBIZ Awards - Recognizing Excellence in Adult Entertainment |publisher=[[XBIZ]] |accessdate=2009-01-03}}</ref> Organized by the adult industry trade magazine [[XBIZ]], the awards were first given in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xbiz.com/news/glbt/102373 |title= XBIZ Awards 2009 Official Nominees Announced. |publisher=[[XBIZ]] |accessdate=2008-12-04}}</ref> The award nominations are submitted by clients, and the winners are voted for by XBiz staff, industry colleagues and participating organizations.<ref name=Winners>{{cite web | title =Web, Studio Winners Announced At XBiz Awards| author=Sherri L. Shaulis| publisher = AVN.com| url = http://business.avn.com/articles/29098.html| date = 2008-02-08| accessdate =2009-01-11 }}</ref> The awards were originally created to recognize achievement in the online adult industry, but in recent years video categories have been added.<ref name=2009Awards>{{cite web | title =XBIZ Announces 2009 Awards Nominees | author=David Sullivan | publisher = AVN.com| url = http://business.avn.com/articles/33645.html| date = 2008-12-05| accessdate =2009-01-11 }}</ref>

revision.text:
'''Pornography addiction''', or more broadly '''overuse of pornography''', is excessive pornography use that interferes with daily life. There is no diagnosis of ''pornography addiction'' in the current [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]] (DSM), and as with the broader proposed diagnosis of [[sexual addiction]], there is debate as to whether or not the behaviors indicate an [[addiction]].<ref name=Downs>{{cite web |last=Downs |first=Martin F. |coauthors=Louise Chang, MD (reviewer) |title=Is Pornography Addictive? Psychologists debate whether people can have an addiction to pornography. |publisher=[[WebMD]] |url=http://men.webmd.com/guide/is-pornography-addictive |date=August 30, 2005 |accessdate=2007-03-22}}</ref>
==Diagnosis as an addiction== ===Dispute about whether or not pornography addiction exists=== There is dispute about whether pornography addiction exists. There is further argument as to whether or not it has harmful effects. Some sex therapists argue that it is a real addiction with serious consequences, while others argue it is not comparable to substance addiction and should not be classed as such.<ref name="bbc">{{cite web|author=Who, What, Why? |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/7371171.stm |title=UK | Magazine | Does sex addiction exist? |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-04-30 |accessdate=2009-08-09}}</ref>
[[Erick Janssen]], PhD, a researcher at the [[Kinsey Institute]], criticizes the application of the term addiction to pornography overuse, arguing that while it describes addiction-like behaviour, treating the users as addicts may not help.<ref name="Downs"/> [[Stephen Andert]], coauthor of "Web Stalkers: Protect Yourself from Internet Criminals & Psychopaths", states "For many people, pornography is a problem. Like alcohol, gambling or drugs, it can take control of a person's life and drag them kicking and screaming or voluntarily into the gutter. The addictive and progressive (or should that be regressive) nature of pornography is well documented." However, Andert identified no source for the claimed documentation.<ref>{{cite book|last= Andert|first=Stephen|coauthors= Donald K. Burleson|title=Web Stalkers: Protect Yourself from Internet Criminals & Psychopaths|publisher=Rampant TechPress|year=2005|pages=339|location=page 359,|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zuqR3KglZfsC&dq=Web+Stalkers&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=June 2009}}</ref>
=== Proposed definition === Aviel Goodman, M.D., proposed general characteristics of all types of addictions in 1990.<ref name="addiction1990def">{{cite journal|last=Goodman|first=Aviel|date=1990|journal=British Journal of Addiction|title=Addiction: Definition And Implications|location=pages 1403-1408|volume=85|issue=11|language=English|url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/119381659/PDFSTART|issn=0952-0481|accessdate=June 2009}}</ref> Pornography addiction is defined, by those who argue that it exists, as a [[psychological addiction]] to, or [[Dependence (behavioral medicine)|dependence]] upon, [[pornography]], characterized by obsessive viewing, reading, and thinking about pornography and sexual themes to the detriment of other areas of one's own life.
== Proposed stages of pornography addiction == Some psychologists and sex therapists (for example [[Kimberly Young]], PhD, and [[Victor Cline]], PhD) have proposed stages in pornography addiction.<ref name="reid"> {{cite book | author = Rory C. Reid | coauthors = Dan Gray | title = Confronting Your Spouse's Pornography Problem | chapter = Assessing a Problem: Pornography Questionnaire | pages = 167–8 | publisher = Silverleaf Press | year = 2006 | isbn = 9781933317434 | url=http://books.google.com/books?id=K-LfGu4syQwC&source=gbs_navlinks_s}} </ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Cline | first = Dr. Victor B. | author-link = Victor Cline | title = Treatment and Healing of Sexual and Pornographic Addictions | url = http://www.obscenitycrimes.org/vbctreat.cfm }}</ref><ref name="clineart">{{Citation | last = Cline | first = Dr. Victor B. | author-link = Victor Cline | title = Pornography's Effects on Adults and Children | url = http://www.obscenitycrimes.org/clineart.cfm }}</ref> <ref> {{cite paper | last = Cline | first = Dr. Victor | authorlink = Victor Cline | title = Victor Cline, Ph.D. Witness Statement, Commission on Child Online Protection | url = http://www.copacommission.org/meetings/hearing3/cline.test.pdf |format=PDF| quote = In the case of pedophiles; the overwhelming majority, in my clinical experience use child pornography and/or create it to stimulate and whet their sexual appetites which they masturbate to then later use as a model for their own sexual acting out with children.[...]Other related studies by D.R. Evens and B.T. Jackson support his thesis. They found that deviant masturbatory fantasy very significantly effected the habit strength of the subject’s sexual deviation }}</ref> <ref name="clineart-desense">{{Citation | last = Cline | first = Dr. Victor B. | author-link = Victor Cline | title = Pornography's Effects on Adults and Children | url = http://www.obscenitycrimes.org/clineart.cfm | quote = The sexual activity depicted in the pornography (no matter how anti-social or deviant) became legitimized. There was an increasing sense that "everybody does it" and this gave them permission to also do it, even though the activity was possibly illegal and contrary to their previous moral beliefs and personal standards. }}</ref> <ref name="clineart-esc">{{Citation | last = Cline | first = Dr. Victor B. | author-link = Victor Cline | title = Pornography's Effects on Adults and Children | url = http://www.obscenitycrimes.org/clineart.cfm | quote = Being married or in a relationship with a willing sexual partner did not solve their problem. Their addiction and escalation were mainly due to the powerful sexual imagery in their minds, implanted there by the exposure to pornography. }}</ref> <ref name="clineart-per">{{Citation | last = Cline | first = Dr. Victor B. | author-link = Victor Cline | title = Pornography's Effects on Adults and Children | url = http://www.obscenitycrimes.org/clineart.cfm | quote = ... an increasing tendency to act out sexually the behaviors viewed in the pornography, including compulsive promiscuity, exhibitionism, group sex, voyeurism, frequenting massage parlors, having sex with minor children, rape, and inflicting pain on themselves or a partner during sex. This behavior frequently grew into a sexual addiction which they found themselves locked into and unable to change or reverse, no matter what the negative consequences were in their life. }}</ref> [[Rory C. Reid]] and Dan Gray<!-- not the one with a wiki article--> note that the stages need not be sequential and not all individuals experience all stages.<ref name="reid"/>
[[Serial killer]] [[Ted Bundy]] stated that his pornography addiction went through stages. As a boy he reported seeing [[softcore pornography]], and that he later viewed [[hardcore pornography]] and [[violent pornography]]. [[Ben Shapiro]], in his book "Porn Generation: How Social Liberalism Is Corrupting Our Future", claimed that this played an influencing role in Bundy's crimes.<ref name="PG_160">{{cite book|last=Shapiro|first=Ben |title=Porn Generation: How Social Liberalism Is Corrupting Our Future|publisher=Regnery Publishing|date=2005|pages=160|ISBN=978-0895260161}}</ref> However, [[Alexander Barnes Dryer]], in his review of the book for [[The New Republic]] states that it was difficult to cite just one flaw with the book, as there were so many.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.powells.com/review/2005_06_30.html|title=Porn Identity:A review by Alexander Barnes Dryer|date=30 June 2005|accessdate=February 2009}}</ref>
== Online pornography addiction == Online pornography addiction involves pornography obtained via the [[Internet]]. Psychologists who support this concept argue that it is stronger, and more addictive, than ordinary pornography addiction because of its wide availability, explicit nature, and the privacy that online viewing offers. Some claim that "addicts" regularly spend extended periods of time searching the internet for new or increasingly hardcore pornography.<ref name="Downs"/>
===Use of content control and monitoring=== Some clinicians and support organizations recommend using voluntary [[Content-control software|content control mechanisms]] (also known as "Internet filters" and "censorware"), internet monitoring, or both as a tool in the treatment of purportedly excessive online pornography use.<ref name="cooper1999" >{{cite journal | last=Cooper | first=Alvin | coauthors=Putnam, Dana E., Planchon, Lynn A., & Boies, Sylvain C. | year=1999 | title=Online Sexual Compulsivity: Getting Tangled in the Net | journal=Sexual Addiction & Compulsivity: The Journal of Treatment and Prevention | volume=6 | issue=2 | pages=79–104 | doi=10.1080/10720169908400182}}</ref><ref name="delmonico1997" >{{cite journal | author=Delmonico, D.L. | year=1997 | title=Cybersex: High Tech Sex Addiction | journal=Sexual Addiction & Compulsivity: The Journal of Treatment and Prevention | volume=4 | issue=2 | pages=159–167 | doi=10.1080/10720169708400139}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.aamft.org/families/Consumer_Updates/Sexual%20Addiction.asp | title=AAMFT Consumer Update - Sexual Addiction | accessdate=2007-06-10 | publisher=American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author=Corley, M. Deborah, Ph.D. | year=2002 | month=Winter | title=Cybersex Addiction | journal=Paradigm | pages=12, 22 | url=http://www.addictionrecov.org/paradigm/P_PR_W02/W02-composite.pdf| format=PDF}}</ref><ref name="layden2005">{{cite journal | author=Layden, Mary Anne, Ph.D. | year=2005 | month=September | title=Cyber Sex Addiction | journal=Advances in Cognitive Therapy | pages=1–2, 4–5 | url=http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&ct=res&cd=2&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.academyofct.org%2FLibrary%2FInfoManage%2FGuide.asp%3FFolderID%3D295%26SessionID%3D&ei=ng-jRtv7PImCgATwws3KDQ&usg=AFQjCNEf86dfie8vIsUfNnNv8F0VGezocA&sig2=2XfdVuPQH5l5A5B3q9A69g | format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://healthymind.com/filters.pdf | title=Choosing an Internet Filter | accessdate=2007-06-10 | author=Bissette, David C., Psy.D. | year=2004 | month=February | format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.recoverypath.ca/therapists_addicts_resources.php | title=Recovery Resources | accessdate=2007-06-10 | publisher=Recovery Path Counselling Services}}</ref>
Sex researcher Alvin Cooper and colleagues suggested several reasons for using filters as a therapeutic measure, including [[curbing]] accessibility that facilitates problematic behavior and encouraging clients to develop coping and relapse prevention strategies.<ref name=cooper1999/> Cognitive therapist Mary Anne Layden suggested that filters may be useful in maintaining environmental control.<ref name=layden2005/> Internet behavior researcher David Delmonico noted that, despite their limitations, filters may serve as a "frontline of protection."<ref name=delmonico1997/>
Filters that target pornography have been included in computer operating systems such as [[Linux]] and are sold as stand-alone applications and devices.
== See also == * [[Anti-pornography movement]] * [[Sexual ethics]] * [[Masturbation addiction]]
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://sexed.org/cur.html People who feel victimized by porn: Let's give them sympathy, not a Congressional hearing] by sex therapist Marty Klein, Ph. D. * [http://www.freespeechcoalition.com/dan_linz.htm Statement of Daniel Linz, Ph.D. on The Science Behind Pornography Addiction] *{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2003/nov/08/gender.weekend7|title=Men and porn|last=Marriott|first=Edward |publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=2008-10-25}} *{{cite news|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/trends/n_9437/ |title=The Porn Myth |author = Naomi Wolf| publisher = New York Magazine| accessdate=2008-10-25}} {{Addiction}} [[Category:Pornography]] [[Category:Sexual addiction]] [[Category:Pseudoscience]] [[Category:Fringe science]]

revision.text:
{{worldwide}} {{wiktionary}} '''Sexting''' (a [[portmanteau]] of '''[[Human sexual behavior|sex]]''' and '''[[text messaging|texting]]''') is the act of sending sexually explicit messages or photos electronically, primarily between cell phones.
==Background== Sexting was reported as early as 2005 in the ''[[Sunday Telegraph]] Magazine'',<ref name=SunTele>{{cite news |title=The One and Only |author=Yvonne Roberts |date=2005-07-31 |accessdate=2009-01-14 |page=22 |quote=Following a string of extramarital affairs and several lurid "sexting" episodes, Warne has found himself home alone, with Simone Warne taking their three children and flying the conjugal coop.}}</ref> and has since been described as taking place worldwide.<ref name=NZ>{{cite news|title=Teen 'sexting' alarms cyber-safety experts |publisher=[[The Press]] |date=2008-07-12 |accessdate=2009-01-14 |author=Phil Hamilton |page=A13}}</ref> It has been reported in [[Great Britain]].<ref name=SunTele/>, Australia,<ref>{{cite news|title=Student knickers in a not; 'Sexting' shocks parents, police |date=2008-06-23 |accessdate=2009-01-14 |publisher=[[mX (newspaper)|mX]] |author=Inga Gilchrist}}</ref> [[New Zealand]],<ref name=NZ/> the [[United States]],<ref name=ABC>{{cite news|title=Sexting |author=Gigi Stone |publisher=[[World News with Charles Gibson|World News Saturday]] |date=2008-12-03 |accessdate=2009-01-14}}</ref>, and [[Canada]].
A January 2009 survey of 1,200 teenagers by [[Burlington, VT|Burlington]], [[Vermont]] television station [[WCAX]] claimed that one in five had sent explicit photos of themselves.<ref name=WCAX>{{cite web|title=Is Your Child "Sexting"? |url=http://www.wcax.com/Global/story.asp?S=9612361&nav=menu183_2 |author=Keagan Harsha |publisher=[[WCAX-TV]] |date=2009-01-03 |accessdate=2009-01-14}}</ref> A sociologist at [[Colorado College]] interviewed 80 children and believes this claim is overblown; she claims; "I had them go through their last ten messages, their last ten photos and I never saw it".<ref>{{cite web|title=Sociologist: Few teens 'sexting' |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/01/11/Sociologist-Few-teens-sexting/UPI-78141231654189/ |date=2009-01-11 |accessdate=2009-05-06 |publisher=[[United Press International|UPI]]}}</ref>
A 2009 UK survey found that 38% of under-18s had "received an offensive or distressing sexual image via text or email".<ref>''[[The Guardian]]'', 7 August 2009, [http://www.guardian.co.uk/lifeandstyle/2009/aug/07/sexting-teenagers-mobile-phones You don't know what sexting is?]</ref>
==Sociology== Sexting is a result of advances in technology enabling new forms of social interaction. Messages with sexual content have been exchanged over all forms of historical media. Newer technology allows photographs and videos, which are intrinsically more explicit and have greater impact. A social danger with sexting is that material can be very easily and widely promulgated, over which the originator has no control.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=719928 |publisher=National Nine News |title=Kids face porn charges over 'sexting' |accessdate=2009-01-20}}</ref>
The Institute for Responsible Online and Cell-Phone Communication [http://www.iroc2.org (I.R.O.C.<sup>2</sup>)] is a New Jersey based 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization dedicated to educating communities about proactively protecting themselves online with digital responsibility through their [http://www.sextingisstupid.com "Sexting is Stupid"] program.
==Legal cases== In 2007, 32 Australian teenagers from the state of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] were prosecuted as a result of sexting activity.<ref>{{cite web|title=Malice in Wonderland |url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/technology/malice-in-wonderland/2008/08/09/1218139163632.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 |date=2008-08-10 |accessdate=2009-01-14 |author=Liz Porter |publisher=[[The Age]]}}</ref> [[Child pornography]] charges were brought against six teenagers in [[Greensburg, Pennsylvania]] in January 2009 after three girls sent sexually explicit photographs to three male classmates.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sexting craze leads to child pornography charges |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/jan/14/child-pornography-sexting |date=2009-01-14 |accessdate=2009-01-14 |publisher=[[Guardian News and Media]]}}</ref>
In 2008, a Virginia assistant-principal was charged with possession of child pornography and related crimes after he had been asked to investigate a rumored sexting incident at the high school where he worked. Upon finding a student in possession of a photo on his phone that depicted the torso of a girl wearing only underpants, her arms mostly covering her breasts, the assistant principal showed the image to the principal who instructed him to preserve the photo on his computer as evidence, which he did. While the court later ruled that the photo did not constitute child pornography because under Virginia law, nudity alone is not enough to qualify an image as child pornography; the image must be "sexually explicit". Loudoun County prosecutor James Plowman stands by his initial assessment of the photo and says he would not have pursued the case if the assistant principal would have agreed to resign. The assistant principal had to get a second mortgage on his house and spend $150,000 in attorneys' fees to clear his name.<ref name=Zetter>Kim Zetter, [http://blog.wired.com/27bstroke6/2009/04/sexting-hysteri.html 'Sexting' Hysteria Falsely Brands Educator as Child Pornographer], Wired.com (Apr. 3, 2009).</ref><ref>Ting-Yi Oei, ''[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/17/AR2009041702663_pf.html My Students. My Cellphone. My Ordeal.]'', The Washington Post (Apr. 19, 2009).</ref>
In Fort Wayne, Indiana, a teenage boy was indicted on felony obscenity charges for allegedly sending a photo of his genitals to several female classmates. Another boy was charged with child pornography in a similar case.<ref>Martha Irvine, ''[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29017808/ Porn charges for 'sexting' stir debate]'', Associated Press (Feb. 4, 2009).</ref>
Police investigated an incident at Margaretta High School in Castalia, Ohio in which a 17-year-old area girl allegedly sent nude pictures of herself to her former boyfriend, and the pictures started circulating around the high school after the two got into a fight.<ref>''[http://www.sanduskyregister.com/articles/2009/03/19/front/1232333.txt Castalia police look into complaint of nude photos sent by cell phone]'', Sandusky Register (Mar. 20, 2009).</ref> The 17-year-old girl was charged with being an "unruly child" based on her juvenile status.<ref>Leslie Bixler, [http://www.thenews-messenger.com/article/20090403/NEWS01/904030302/1002/rss01 Girl, 17, charged for sending naked photographs] The News-Messenger (Apr. 3, 2009).</ref>
Two southwest Ohio teenagers were charged with contributing to the delinquency of a minor, a first-degree misdemeanor, for sending or possessing nude photos on their cell phones of two 15-year-old classmates.<ref>''[http://www.wlwt.com/news/18855563/detail.html Two Mason Teenagers Charged In 'Sexting' Case]'', WLWT (Mar. 4, 2009).</ref>
The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] of [[Pennsylvania]] filed a lawsuit against [[Wyoming County, Pennsylvania|Wyoming County]] [[district attorney]] George Skumanick Jr. on March 25, 2009 for threatening to prosecute teenage girls for distributing nude photos of themselves.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.aclupa.org/pressroom/aclusueswyomingcountydafor.htm|publisher=American Civil Liberties Union|title=ACLU Sues Wyoming County D.A. For Threatening Teenage Girls With Child Pornography Charges Over Photos Of Themselves|date=2009-03-25}}</ref> The case is<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aclupa.org/legal/legaldocket/milleretalvskumanick|title=Miller, et al v. Skumanick|publisher=ACLU of Pennsylvania|accessdate=2009-03-29}}</ref> ''Miller, et al v. Skumanick''. On [[CBS News]]'s ''[[The Early Show]]'', Skumanick stated in an interview with [[Julie Chen]] that his office decided to make an offer of limiting penalties to probation if they attend a sexual harassment program.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/03/27/earlyshow/main4896577.shtml|title=Sexting Girls Facing Porn Charge Sue D.A.|date=2009-03-27|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=2009-03-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-big-questions/200903/my-1st-bra-my-1st-sexual-offense|title=My 1st Bra, My 1st Sexual Offense|date=2009-03-29|publisher=Psychology Today Blogs|accessdate=2009-04-02}}</ref>
==Legislative responses== Vermont lawmakers introduced a bill in April 2009 to legalize the consensual exchange of graphic images between two people 13 to 18 years old. Passing along such images to others would remain a crime.<ref>''[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,514875,00.html Vermont Considers Legalizing Teen 'Sexting']'', Associated Press (Apr. 13, 2009).</ref>
In Ohio, a county prosecutor and two lawmakers proposed a law that would reduce sexting from a [[felony]] to a first degree [[misdemeanor]], and eliminate the possibility of a teenage offender being labeled a sex offender for years. The proposal was supported by the parents of Jessie Logan, a Cincinnati 18-year-old who committed suicide after the naked picture of herself which she sexted was forwarded to people in her high school.<ref>Dick Russ, ''[http://www.wkyc.com/print.aspx?storyid=111478 Ohio to address 'sexting' laws]'', WKYC-TV (Apr. 13, 2009).</ref>
Utah lawmakers lessened the penalty for sexting for someone younger than 18 to a misdemeanor from a felony.<ref>''[http://www.standard.net/live/news/legislative/166693/ Utah lawmakers OK bill on 'sexting']'', Associated Press (Mar. 11, 2009).</ref>
==In popular culture== The episode of ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' titled "Crush" featured a case which referenced sexting frequently throughout the episode. <ref>''[http://familyinternet.about.com/b/2009/05/05/sexting-goes-primetime.htm Sexting Goes Primetime] Retrieved on 2009-06-01''.</ref>
==See also== *[[Moral panic]] *[[Deviancy amplification spiral]] *[[Rainbow party (sexuality)|Rainbow Party]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * [http://www.tdn.com/articles/2009/01/06/this_day/doc4962b83d178a9868969063.txt The Middle Ages: Young people, texting and sexting], Susan Reimer, [[The Baltimore Sun]], 6 January 2009. *http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/WorldNews/story?id=6456834&page=1
