{{Unreferenced|date=April 2009}} '''Clothed female, naked (or nude) male''' (on the internet sometimes abbreviated to '''CFNM''') is a genre of [[erotica]] featuring one or more [[nudity|nude]] men and one or more clothed women. The purpose of this type of pornography is that the male is fully (or mostly) nude and the women around him (or them) deny him (or them) the pleasure of seeing them in the same state of undress. It is sometimes described as a [[sexual fantasy]] depicting such a scenario.
The general theme of CFNM is fairly broad, encompassing several different types of sexual and nonsexual scenarios. The most common subdivisions of the genre as a sexual scenario involve activity under the rubric of [[female domination]], [[male submission]], [[exhibitionism]], or [[entertainment]]; combination of all categories is somewhat rare, although several web sites cater to the sub genres separately.{{Fact|date=March 2009}} CFNM is also considered by some to be a form of [[sexual objectification]] of men by women or as a [[role reversal]].
The establishment of CFNM as a specific form of erotic interest did not occur until the creation of the Internet at which time the concept was explored in various discussion forums, and then named.{{Fact|date=March 2009}}
The opposite is [[clothed male, naked female]] (CMNF).
== CFNM fantasy and humiliation/punishment ==
Unlike CMNF, CFNM is not divided into categories Nice CFNM and Hard CFNM. There are many reasons why the male participants receive pleasure from the CFNM experience. Many males enjoy being completely nude around females and do not tend to be disappointed that the females are fully clothed while experiencing the sexual pleasure given by females including [[masturbation]]. While the male figures in CMNF are almost fully clothed, the females in CFNM often are seen in only their undergarments.
However some male participants often feel humiliated during the experience. Like the females in Hard CMNF, the focus is on the embarrassment/humiliation he experiences in the situation.
== CFNM in music video == * [[Connection (Elastica song)|Connection by Elastica]]
==CFNM in film== ''[[Porky's Revenge]]'' (1985) has a scene in which the boys' basketball team is tricked into thinking that they were going to have an orgy with the cheerleaders. Before they jump into the pool the boys strip down to their boxers and the girls to their swimsuits. Then the girls trick the boys into taking off their boxers while the girls throw a different swimsuit that came from a bag that they passed around so they could keep their suits on. When the boys approach the girls, the girls raced to the deep end and made the boys get out without their suits, and the girls filmed them.

{{refimprove|date=April 2009}} '''''Gay-for-pay''''' describes male (and, less frequently, female) actors, pornographic stars, or [[prostitution|sex workers]] who self-identify as [[heterosexuality|heterosexual]] but who are paid to act or perform [[homosexuality|gay]] professionally. The term has also applied to other professions and even companies with the same core concerns and criticism in place.<ref name="Blazin Squad, gay 4 pay?">{{cite web |last=Phillips |first=James |title=Blazin Squad, gay 4 pay? |publisher=Pink News |date=September 19, 2006 |url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/news/opinion/2005-2514.html |accessdate=2007-10-19}}</ref><ref name="Klixxx Home: Gay Webmaster Resources">{{cite web |last=Palmer |first=Brandon |title=Klixxx Home: Gay Webmaster Resources, Gay 4 Pay |publisher=Klixxx |date=September 19, 2006 |url=http://www.klixxx.com/gay/gay4pay.shtml |accessdate=2007-10-19}}</ref> The stigma of being gay or labeled as such has steadily eroded since the [[Stonewall riots]] began the modern [[gay rights]] movement in 1969. Through the 1990s, mainstream movie and television actors have been more willing to portray homosexuality, as the threat of any backlash against their careers has lessened and society's acceptance of gay and lesbian people has increased.<ref name="pewreport">{{cite book |last=Pew Global Attitudes Project |title=Views of a Changing World |url=http://pewglobal.org/reports/display.php?ReportID=185 |format=.PDF |year=2003 |month=June |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher=The Pew Research Center For The People & The Press | oclc=52547041 |accessdate=2007-07-11}}</ref>
In the gay pornography industry, which uses amateurs as well as professional actors, the term ''gay-for-pay'' refers to actors labeled or believed to be straight but who engage in same-sex activities and/or intercourse for money. Some actors who are actually gay or bisexual will be marketed as straight to appeal to the "allure of the unattainable", because straight men (or those newly [[coming out]]) are [[virgin]]s to sex with other men, and "as in most gay male settings, the young, the muscular, and the unfamiliar are more sought."<ref name="sought"> Leap, William L [http://books.google.com/books?id=YXUP4JmJo_0C&pg=PA62&ots=XhkEisbf6Z&dq=troll+gay+sex&sig=6kAawESJfOwZvrWhW2EFB-srfzU "Public Sex/Gay Space By William L. Leap, 1999, pg. 62"] Retrieved on 2007-06-06.</ref>
__TOC__ ==Mainstream actors== A heterosexual actor who plays an [[LGBT]] character in movies, television shows, or theatre may have extra attention paid to the possibility that they were themselves gay, although that trend has diminished.<ref> [http://books.google.com/books?id=qMOnrrJqRr8C ''Still acting gay: male homosexuality in modern drama''] John M. Clum, Palgrave Macmillan, 2000; ISBN 0312223846, 9780312223847.</ref> Some prominent examples include: [[Christopher Meloni]] in ''[[Oz]]'', [[Will Smith]] in ''[[Six Degrees of Separation (film)|Six Degrees of Separation]]'', [[Hilary Swank]] in ''[[Boys Don't Cry (film)|Boys Don't Cry]]'', [[Eric McCormack]] in ''[[Will and Grace]]'', [[Keanu Reeves]] in ''[[My Own Private Idaho]]'', [[Matt Damon]] in ''[[The Talented Mr. Ripley (film)|The Talented Mr. Ripley]]'', [[Heath Ledger]] and [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] in ''[[Brokeback Mountain]]'', [[Judy Davis]] in ''[[Serving in Silence]]'', [[Sean Penn]] in ''[[Milk (film)|Milk]]'', [[Charlize Theron]] in ''[[Monster (film)|Monster]]'', and [[Mitch Hewer]] in ''[[Skins (TV series)|Skins]]''. In this sense, their characters are gay, rather than any explicit sexual act that the actors may perform.
Many LGBT roles are purposely void of overt displays of sexuality that are commonplace for heterosexual roles. Often the "big gay scene" involves a lip-on-lip kissing or implied sexual coupling. One storyline from the popular primetime TV series ''[[Will and Grace]]'' centered on the two gay male characters protesting [[NBC]] for editing out the big gay kiss that had been promised.<ref>Season 2-14 of ''[[Will and Grace]]''; "Acting Out" originally aired February 22, 2000. Jack is outraged when NBC decides not to air a gay kiss as promised.</ref>
Some in the gay community have criticized Hollywood actors and film studios for "whitewashing" the gayness of some gay characters. More recently, "playing gay" in [[Independent film|Indie films]] (usually for lower pay) has become an opportunity for Hollywood actors to showoff their ''gravitas'' and acting range like [[Russell Crowe]] in ''[[The Sum of Us]]''.<ref name="Gay 4 Pay - Straight Actors">{{cite web |last=von Metzke |first=Ross |title=Gay 4 Pay - Straight Actors in Gay Roles |publisher=Gay Wired |date=[[September 21]], [[2007]] |url=http://www.gaywired.com/article.cfm?section=67&id=16561 |accessdate=2007-10-19}}</ref>
Up through the early 1990s, when [[Tom Hanks]] played a gay character suffering from AIDS in ''[[Philadelphia (film)|Philadelphia]]'', most Hollywood actors avoided playing homosexual or transgender characters for fear of being identified too closely with the characters they played. (British actors had been "playing gay" for at least a decade; e.g., [[Daniel Day-Lewis]], [[Rupert Graves]], and [[Jeremy Irons]]). More recently actors have been emboldened to take on all manner of roles including [[LGBT]] characters like [[James Marsden]] in the psychological thriller/AIDS drama ''[[The 24th Day]]'' and the ensemble drama ''[[Heights]]'', [[Guy Pearce]] in ''[[The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert]]'', [[Clive Owen]] in ''[[Bent (play)|Bent]]'' and [[Paul Rudd]] in ''[[The Object of My Affection]]''.<ref name="Gay 4 Pay - Straight Actors"/>
==Pornography== In gay pornographic movies, actors who identify themselves as heterosexual, but who nevertheless perform explicit sexual acts with other males on film (e.g., [[Ryan Idol]], [[Clay Maverick]], [[Mike Branson]], [[Jeff Stryker]], [[Wolf Hudson]], [[Christian XXX|Christian]], [[Aaron James (porn star)|Aaron James]], [[Peter North (actor)|Peter North]], [[Joe Dallesandro]]) do not face the same stigmas as the mainstream acting counterparts and indeed can rise quickly to being featured actors. These actors often play the "[[Top (sex)|top]]" roles but this is not always the case, such as with [[Kristen Bjorn]] and some [[Bel Ami (adult film company)|Bel Ami]] models. Kurt Wild, who appeared as a bottom in [[Lucas Entertainment]]'s ''Gigolos'', is married with three children.<ref>[http://bananaguide.com/article/18084 Kurt Wild: Married with children], Banana Guide, January 4, 2008.</ref>
Female-on-female sex in straight porn does not usually carry the same level of stigma as male gay-for-pay sex. Indeed it is a strong fantasy subject so references to female porn actors as gay-for-pay are more rare.
There is a proliferation of gay pornographic videos with a story that features an ostensibly heterosexual male being seduced into a gay male sexual act. An example of this is [[Latino Fan Club]], a film production company which specializes in producing amateur gay pornographic films in which pornographic actors are billed as "Straight Latino Street Thugs" appear to reluctantly have sex with one another. The video production company website also offers contact information for hiring these "straight" models as [[escort]]s and [[prostitute]]s.
People involved in the gay pornographic industry consider that some gay pornographic actors who identify as straight are not truly heterosexual. Because some gay men consider heterosexual men to be objects of fantasy, some gay porn producers have almost certainly described some actors as heterosexual to increase sales and publicity for their product.<ref name="Proven Strait: Movie Review">{{cite magazine |last=Benton |first=Angel |authorlink= |coauthors=The JUB crew |title=Proven Strait: Movie Review |publisher=Just Us Boys (magazine) |date=October 2007, Volume 3 - Issue 5, page 46 |url=http://www.Justusboys.com |accessdate=2007-10-19}}</ref> Moreover, many gay or bisexual men who star in gay porn films may wish to be identified publicly as heterosexual for personal or professional reasons.{{Fact|date=February 2009}}
Some straight actors have started acting in gay porn only to be accused of being gay while others first step was to strictly do solo scenes.<ref name="Fabscout">{{cite magazine |last=Benton |first=Angel |authorlink= |coauthors=The JUB crew |title=Fabscout |publisher=Just Us Boys (magazine) |date=October 2007, Volume 3 - Issue 5, page 34 |url=http://www.Justusboys.com |accessdate=2007-10-19}}</ref> The higher pay scale and profile within a production often leads to group scenes where a straight actor only "tops". Many times a "top" actor will then be sought as a bottom and the debut is often treated as a notable event or even its own release.<ref name="Andrew Justice">{{cite magazine |last=Benton |first=Angel |authorlink= |coauthors=The JUB crew |title=Andrew Justice |publisher=Just Us Boys (magazine) |date=October 2007, Volume 3 - Issue 5, page 16 |url=http://www.Justusboys.com |accessdate=2007-10-19}}</ref>
===Motivation=== Most male pornographic actors are paid much less than their female counterparts in straight porn. Male porn actors, however, get paid more, on the average, in gay porn than in straight porn. There are also more opportunities to become a "star" in gay porn than in straight porn where the focus of attention remains on the actresses. As a response to criticism in the gay community, some of these actors (perhaps with the advice of their publicists) would sometimes claim that they are in fact bisexual although they are indeed "gay" for the money.
There is also a theory that some of the "straight" actors are actually [[closeted]] or [[bisexual]] and using their acting in gay porn is a legitimate career step which allows them to also experiment with their sexuality.<ref name="Getting Behind Gay Porn Productions">{{cite web |last=McMillan |first=Dennis |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Getting Behind Gay Porn Productions |publisher=[[San Francisco Bay Times]] |date=[[January 27]], [[2005]] |url=http://www.sfbaytimes.com/index.php?sec=article&article_id=3891 |accessdate=2007-10-14}}</ref>
==Sex workers== In the sex worker industry, the term may also be applied to straight and bisexual people of all genders (including "[[male escort]]s") who have sexual contact or scenes with a client or another sex worker of the same gender. Although sexual contact is often involved, sex scenes or solo scenes (like masturbating to climax) or even a [[BDSM]] scene for the client's stimulation can take place. Sexual arousal without direct sexual contact may also occur in such niche trade like muscle worship. As in porn work, a gay-identity is not necessary to make money from a gay clients and consumers.
==Go-go dancers== [[Go-go dancing]] originated in the 1960s and were eventually appropriated by [[burlesque]] and [[striptease]] establishments, which in turn became known as "go-go bars" but many [[gay club]]s had male go-go dancers (called ''go-go boys'') during the period 1965-1968. After that, few gay clubs had go-go dancers until 1988, when go-go dancing again became fashionable (and has remained so ever since). "Go-go dancers" that perform at night clubs, special parties, [[circuit parties]] or [[rave]] dances in colorful bright costumes (which may include battery operated lights), with fire sticks, or with a snake can also be called ''performance art dancers'' or ''box dancers''. Large [[circuit parties]] and gay clubs often have very attractive go-go boys of all sexualities who will allow patrons to touch and rub them but only for [[tip]]s. This is typical in Thai venues, such as in [[Sunee Plaza]], Pattaya. Some criticize the practice of employing straight dancers to perform erotically for gay audiences when gay performers are available.<ref name="Hillary and Condi and Dykes">{{cite web |last=Musto |first=Michael |authorlink=Michael Musto |coauthors= |title=Hillary and Condi and Dykes, Oh My!: Plus items of purely prosthetic appeal. |publisher=[[The Village Voice]] |date=[[September 25]], [[2007]] |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/nyclife/0739,musto,77903,15.html |accessdate=2007-10-19}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|LGBT|Portal LGBT.svg}} {{Portal|Pornography|Nuvola apps aktion.png}} * ''[[The Fluffer]]'', film about a fictional gay-for-pay actor
==References== {{reflist}}
{{LGBT slang}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gay-For-Pay}} [[Category:Pornography terms]] [[Category:Sexual orientation and society]] [[Category:Sexual slang]] [[Category:LGBT slang]] [[Category:Gay male pornography]]

[[Image:Pin-up 1.jpg|thumb|[[Pin-up]] art by Patrick Hitte]]'''Upskirt''' is a [[:slang]] term usually referring to '''up skirt photography''', images of the view up a woman's [[skirt]] (as seen from underneath), including shots of a woman's [[underwear]] or crotch, or exposing her [[vulva]] or [[buttocks]]. Alternatively, an "upskirt"<!-- Deviates from MoS. Quotes here to demonstrate this term is used as a regular noun. --> may be a [[video]], an [[Drawing|illustration]], or simply a view.
Upskirt photographs are common on [[Internet pornography|pornographic websites]].<ref name=SeatUpskirt>{{cite news | first = Maureen | last = O'Hagan | title = 'Upskirt' photographs deemed lewd but legal | url = http://archives.seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/texis.cgi/web/vortex/display?slug=voyeur20m0&date=20020920 | work = [[The Seattle Times]] | publisher = [[The Seattle Times|The Seattle Times Company]] | date = 2002-09-20 | accessdate = 2006-12-26 | quote = So-called "upskirt cams," sometimes called "upskirt photos" or "upskirt voyeur pictures," are a hot commodity in the world of Internet pornography. }}</ref>
==Voyeurism== While upskirt images may be captured consensually, many viewers seek such images taken surreptitiously (and presumably without the subject's consent). The creation and viewing of this type of upskirt are a form of [[voyeurism]]. The advent of [[cell phone]]s fitted with [[camera]]s (a.k.a. [[camera phone]]s) is often credited for the surge in this type of photograph.<ref>{{cite news | first = Jo | last = Napolitano | title = Hold It Right There, And Drop That Camera | url = http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C04E1D8163CF932A25751C1A9659C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all | work = [[The New York Times]] | publisher = [[The New York Times Company]] | date = 2003-12-11 | accessdate = 2008-05-23 | quote = ... the proliferation of camera phones had helped give new life to "up skirt" or "down blouse" photography. }}</ref><ref name=HAPriv>{{cite news | first = Michael | last = Tsai | title = Privacy issues plague picture phones | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2004/Jan/18/ln/ln20a.html | work = [[The Honolulu Advertiser]] | publisher = [[Gannett Company|Gannett Co.]] | date = 2004-01-18 | accessdate = 2006-12-26 | quote = ... because of the growing popularity of camera-equipped cell phones. }}</ref>
===Legal consideration=== [[Image:The gogo-dancers red G-String.jpg|thumb|A [[Go-Go dancing|Go-Go dancer]]]] ====Australia==== Many states in [[Australia]] have passed laws making it illegal to take upskirt photos in [[public places]] without the subject's consent.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.smh.com.au/news/cameras--videos/upskirting-to-become-a-crime/2006/07/28/1153816375391.html |title= Upskirting to become a crime |accessdate= 2007-06-10 |date= 2006-07-28 |work= smh.com.au |publisher= The Sydney Morning Herald |quote= Voyeurs who secretly take pictures up women's skirts or down their blouses will face a crackdown under draft uniform national laws criminalizing the practice. }}</ref>
====New Zealand==== In [[New Zealand]] it is illegal to take voyeuristic photos of intimate body parts in any setting in which a person has a "reasonable expectation of privacy". This includes public and private settings. It is also illegal to possess or distribute such images.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/topic/story.cfm?c_id=247&objectid=10412411 |title=Law to stop voyeurs filming people |accessdate=2007-06-10 |date=2006-10-25 |work=NZ Herald |publisher=APN Holdings NZ Limited |quote=The punishment can be up to three years' imprisonment. }}</ref>
====United States====
The United States enacted the Video Voyeurism Prevention Act of 2004 to punish those who intentionally capture an individual's private areas without consent, when the person knew the subject had an expectation of privacy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s108-1301 |title=S. 1301 [108th]: Video Voyeurism Prevention Act of 2004 |publisher=GovTrack.us |date= |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref> Additionally, many state laws address the issue as well.<ref>http://www.ncvc.org/ncvc/AGP.Net/Components/documentViewer/Download.aspxnz?DocumentID=40459</ref>
[[Image:Fragonard, The Swing-detail voyeur.jpg|thumb|Detail from [[Jean-Honoré Fragonard|Fragonard's]] ''[[The Swing (painting)|The Swing]]'' (1767)]]
====United Kingdom==== The UK has no specific ban on taking such photos but the activity could be prosecuted as voyeurism under the Sexual Offences Act 2003 or as outraging public decency.<ref>{{cite news |title='Upskirt' pictures on the rise |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/picturegalleries/celebritynews/4805898/Upskirt-pictures-on-the-rise.html |work=Daily Telegraph |date=25 Feb 2009 |accessdate=26 February 2009 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Anasyrma]] * [[Downblouse]] * [[Panchira]]

{{For|the Japanese noodle preparation method|Udon#Cold}} [[Image:Wiki-bukkake-2.png|thumb|right|Illustration depicting the act of bukkake]] '''Bukkake''' (Japanese: ブッカケ) {{Audio|Bukkake.ogg|pronunciation}} (1: IPA: /bu̜ˈk:ake̞/ 2: IPA: /bʊˈkæke/) is a sexual practice that features a person (usually a woman) being [[ejaculation|ejaculated]] on by several men. <ref>{{cite book | last =Paul | first =Pamela | title =[[Pornified]]: How Pornography Is Damaging Our Lives, Our Relationships, and Our Families | publisher =Owl Books |date=2006-08-08 | pages =61 | isbn = 978-0-8050-8132-9 0-8050-8132-1 }} </ref><ref name=partridge>{{cite book|title=The New Partridge Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English: A-I|publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]]|author=Eric Partridge, Tom Dalzell, Terry Victor |year=2006|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=4YfsEgHLjboC&source=gbs_navlinks_s|isbn=0415259371|pages=288}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title= The Illustrated Dictionary of Sex | publisher =Lotus Press |date=2007-11-30 | pages =35 | isbn = 978-8189093594 8189093592 }} </ref><ref>{{cite book | title= La palabra y el hombre | publisher = Universidad Veracruzana |year=1957 }} </ref><ref name=Routledge>{{cite book|title=The Routledge Dictionary of Modern American Slang and Unconventional English|publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]]|author=Tom Dalzell |year=2008|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5F-YNZRv-VMC&source=gbs_navlinks_s|isbn=0415371821|page=138}}</ref><ref name=Fantabulosa/> It may also involve the [[semen]] [[Seminophagia|being eaten]].<ref name=cake/> Bukkake is similar to the related practice of [[gokkun]], in which several men ejaculate into a container for the receiver to drink.<ref name=Routledge/><ref name=cake/> The practice is a relatively prevalent [[List of pornographic sub-genres|niche]] in contemporary [[pornographic films]], some of which involve hundreds of male participants.<ref name=partridge/><ref name=Routledge/> There is debate on whether to class bukkake as a [[paraphilia]] such as hygrophilia, sexual arousal from contact with [[bodily secretions]].<ref name=cake/>
==Etymology== Bukkake is the noun form of the [[Japanese language|Japanese]] verb ''bukkakeru'' (ぶっ掛ける, to dash or splash water),<ref>[http://www.seekjapan.jp/article-1/744/The+(Almost)+Complete+Japanzine+Dictionary+of+Japan+Sex Dictionary of Japan Sex]</ref> and means "To dash", "splash" or "heavy splash".<ref name=Routledge/><ref name=Fantabulosa>{{cite book|title=Fantabulosa: a dictionary of Polari and gay slang|publisher=[[Continuum International Publishing Group]]|author=Paul Baker |year=2004|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=T72TJfZoywAC&source=gbs_navlinks_s|isbn=0826473431|page=90}}</ref> The compound verb can be decomposed into two verbs: ''butsu'' (ぶつ) and ''kakeru'' (掛ける). ''Butsu'' literally means to hit, but in this usage it appears to be an intensive prefix as in ''buttamageru'' (ぶったまげる, "completely astonished") or ''butchigiri'' (ぶっちぎり, "overwhelming win").
''Kakeru'' in this context means to shower or pour. The word ''bukkake'' is often used in Japanese to describe pouring out water with sufficient momentum to cause splashing or spilling. Indeed, bukkake is used in Japan to describe a type of dish where the broth is poured on top of noodles, as in bukkake-[[udon]] and bukkake-[[soba]].
==History== The common legend is that bukkake originated in ancient Japan, where an unfaithful woman was publicly punished by being tied up as every man in town ejaculated onto her face.<ref name=cake>''[http://abstracts.co.allenpress.com/pweb/sexo2005/document/50214 Bake a Cake? Exposing the Sexual Practice of Bukkake]''. Hudson, Jeff; Doong, Nicholas. XVII World Congress of Sexology, Montreal, Canada.</ref><ref name=americanbukkake/> The existence of such a practice in ancient Japan is disputed, and the supposed ancient origins of bukkake may be an [[urban legend]].
Bukkake was first represented in [[pornographic films]] in the mid to late 1980s in Japan.<ref name=Fantabulosa/><ref name=cake/> A significant factor in the development of bukkake as a pornographic form was the mandatory censorship of genitalia in Japan.<ref name=wired/> Genitals must be [[Pixelization|pixelated]] by a "mosaic".<ref name=wired/> One consequence of this is that Japanese pornography tends to focus more on the face and body of actresses, rather than their genitals.<ref name=wired/> Since film producers could not show penetration they sought other ways to depict sex acts without violating Japanese law.<ref name=wired/> Semen was not required to be censored, thus creating a loophole for harder sex scenes.<ref name=wired/> The first known recorded and publicly released act of ''bukkake'' in [[Japanese pornography]] was in the movie {{nihongo|''Mascot Note''|マスカットノート}} starring Matsuoka Aiko, released in December 1986, the act being previously known simply as {{nihongo|''gansha''|顔射|"facial ejaculation"}}. However, popularization of the act and the term for it has been credited to director [[Kazuhiko Matsumoto]] in 1998.<ref name=wired>{{cite web |url=http://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2004/04/63009?currentPage=2 |title=Fix for Japan Pop-Culture Addicts |accessdate=2009-07-01 |author=Xeni Jardin |date=2004-12-04 |work= |publisher=[[Wired (magazine)|wired.com]]}}</ref> The practice then spread from Japan to American and then European pornography after US porn producers discovered Japanese bukkake videos in the late 1990s.<ref name=cake/><ref name=americanbukkake/><ref name=Sigel>{{cite book|title=International exposure: perspectives on modern European pornography, 1800-2000|publisher=[[Rutgers University Press]]|author=Lisa Z. Sigel |year=2005|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=KiyY_nlqaQEC&source=gbs_navlinks_s|isbn=0813535190|page=189}}</ref> There was an economic advantage for Western pornographers to produce bukkake films, since they only require one actress and often amateur male performers whose pay-rates are low.<ref name=Sigel/> However bukkake is less popular than some other porn niches, possibly because the subordination of the woman does not appeal to many consumers, or because in pornography cum-shots are normally the climax of a scene, rather than the "main event".<ref name=Sigel/>
The practice then spread to [[gay pornography]], in which several men ejaculate on another man.<ref name=Fantabulosa/><ref name=cake/> Pornographic use of the word has been expanded by the ''[[lesbian bukkake]]'' series, in which several women purportedly [[Female ejaculation|ejaculate]] on another woman.<ref>{{cite video | people = [[Ashley Blue]] (Director) | title = Lesbian Bukkake | medium = [[VHS]] and [[DVD]] | publisher = JM Productions |accessdate=2007-04-20 |date= 2004 |url=http://www.iafd.com/title.asp?title=Lesbian+Bukkake+1&year=2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Sargeant |first=Jack |authorlink=Jack Sargeant |year=2006 |month=November |volume=9 |issue=5 |title=Filth and Sexual Excess: Some Brief Reflections on Popular Scatology |journal=Media and Culture Journal |url=http://www.journal.media-culture.org.au/0610/03-sargeant.php |accessdate=2007-04-19}}</ref>
The 17th World Congress of [[Sexology]] in Montreal in July 2005 included a presentation on bukkake.<ref name=cake/>
==Examples of bukkake pornography== ''American Bukkake'' is a film series focussing on bukkake produced by [[JM Productions]] and directed by Jim Powers.<ref name=americanbukkake>pp.31-37 ''My, My American Bukkake'' by Susannah Breslin in Greta Christina, Daniel Clowes, ''Best Erotic Comics 2008, illustrated edition'', Last Gasp, 2007. ISBN 0867196866</ref> JM shoots scenes in [[North Hollywood]] every Wednesday night, for three weeks running, every third month.<ref name=americanbukkake/> The male performers are members of the public who have replied to newspaper adverts or have called the "bukkake hotline" telephone number.<ref name=americanbukkake/> Normally 50 to 100 men take part, who are paid $35 each.<ref name=americanbukkake/> Some of the men disguise their identities by wearing masks or bandanas over their faces.<ref name=americanbukkake/> The female performers are professional pornographic actresses, and are paid $500 for a shoot that usually lasts around two hours.<ref name=americanbukkake/> On [[21 May]] [[2001]] JM's offices were raided by twenty officers from the [[Los Angeles Police Department|LAPD]]. The officers confiscated several bukkake-themed videos. In response Jeff Steward stated, "Some guy swims in feces on MTV, and that's OK? But for a girl to swallow 80 loads of cum is obscene? I dont think so." On the evening of the raid, Jim Powers was in North Hollywood filming another ''American Bukkake'' film. In reference to what he considered the injustice of the raid, he announced to the men involved, "We're doing this for all of America".<ref name=americanbukkake/>
''German Goo Girls'' (GGG) is a German film series from [[John Thompson Productions]], which has helped to make the company one of the best known and top selling German and European porn studios.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ainews.com/Archives/Story9757.phtml |title=Black Widow Lands 4 Noms for Its First AVN Award Show |accessdate=2009-04-26 |author=Wayne Hentai PR |date=2005-11-30 |work= |publisher=ainews.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://ainews.com/Archives/Story7717.phtml |title=Black Widow & GGG in USA: Still Alive & Kicking|accessdate=2009-04-26 |author=Wayne Hentai PR |date=2004-10-14|publisher=ainews.com}}</ref><ref name=orgazmik>{{cite web |url=http://e.orgazmik.com/sextrends/biography/John%20Thompson/1129.htm |title=John Thompson |accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=e.orgazmik.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.xbiz.com/news/news_piece.php?id=104959 |title=HotMovies, EuroRevenue Partner to Release John Thompson Content |accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=xbiz.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.germangoogirlsvod.com |title=HotMovies, GGG video on demand |accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=xbiz.com}}</ref><ref name=largest>{{cite web |url=http://www.xbiz.com/news/news_piece.php?id=10420 |title=EuroRevenue Claims Europe's Largest Producer|accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=xbiz.com}}</ref> The GGG series started in [[1998]].<ref name=orgazmik/> It focuses on bukkake <ref name=VOD>{{cite web |url=http://www.xbiz.com/news/news_piece.php?id=101416|title=John Thompson Signs VOD Deal With Orgazmik |accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=xbiz.com}}</ref>, however also features gangbangs, [[lesbian sex]] and very occasionally [[urolagnia]], and is the most successful of all JT productions. GGG is [[Film distribution|distributed]] in the United States by [[Black Widow Productions]], who had to move to a larger warehouse to cope with demand for the series. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://business.avn.com/articles/18745.html |title=BLACK WIDOW RELOCATES TO ACCOMMODATE DEMAND FOR GGG LINE|accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=business.avn.com}}</ref><ref name=fournoms>{{cite web |url=http://ainews.com/Archives/Story9757.phtml |title=Black Widow Lands 4 Noms for Its First AVN Award Show|accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=ainews.com}}</ref> GGG won in the 'Special Video production' category at the 2004 [[Venus Awards]]. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.venus-berlin.com/2004/en/presse/download/venus.2004.news.2004-10-22.award-gewinner.en.pdf |title=VENUS AWARD Winner 2004|accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=venus-berlin.com}}</ref> GGG title 'Cissie's Cum Show' was nominated in the 'Best Specialty Release – Other Genre' category at the 2006 [[AVN Awards]] <ref name=fournoms/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.archive.org/web/20051126013107/http://www.avnawards.com/2006nominations.pdf |title=Specialty Awards|accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=avnawards.com}}</ref> The series also won the Adam Film World 'Most Outrageous Sex Series' award in 2005, and is discussed in the 2008 book 'Alles über Porno!', by Marcel Feige. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://ainews.com/Archives/Story8852.phtml |title=GGG Takes AFW Honor|accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=ainews.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://translate.google.co.uk/translate?hl=en&sl=de&u=http://astore.amazon.de/marcelfeige-21/detail/3896028359&ei=thujSdGDOqSLjAfauLjlCw&sa=X&oi=translate&resnum=6&ct=result&prev=/search%3Fq%3DAlles%2B%25C3%25BCber%2BPorno!%2Bggg%2B%2522Alles%2B%25C3%25BCber%2BPorno!%2522%26hl%3Den%26lr%3D%26safe%3Doff%26sa%3DN%26as_qdr%3Dall |title=Marcel Feige. Writers|accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=astore.amazon.de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.schwarzkopf-schwarzkopf.de/lustliebe/rotlicht/allesueberporno/allesueberporno.php |title=ALLES ÜBER PORNO!|accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=schwarzkopf-schwarzkopf.de}}</ref> Importing the GGG title 'Vollgespritzt & Vollgepisst' to [[Canada]] is prohibited, due to it being deemed [[Obscenity|obscene]] by the Canadian authorities.<ref name=gomorrahy>{{cite web |url=http://www.gomorrahy.com/cbsa-piu-q1-08.pdf |title=Quarterly List of Admissible and Prohibited Titles |accessdate=2009-05-01|publisher=gomorrahy.com}}</ref> GGG launched the career of [[Annette Schwarz]]; so far the only actress to have worked with John Thompson to have gone onto a successful mainstream porn career in the United States.<ref name=VOD/>
==Criticism== Some feminists have described bukkake as a [[sexual fetishism|fetish]] culture somehow "beyond sex". Others describe bukkake as symbolic [[group rape]], with its primary purpose as the humiliation, degradation and [[Sexual objectification|objectification of women]],<ref>{{cite journal | last =Franklin | first =Karen | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Enacting Masculinity: Antigay Violence and Group Rape as Participatory Theater | journal =Journal of NSRC | volume =1 | issue =2 | pages =25–40 | publisher =California State Press |month=April | year=2004 | url =http://caliber.ucpress.net/doi/pdfplus/10.1525/srsp.2004.1.2.25 | doi =10.1525/srsp.2004.1.2.25 <!--Retrieved from URL by DOI bot--> | id = | accessdate = 2007-01-26 }}</ref> and that the use of ejaculation is part of a humiliation ritual and generally does not involve any of the female characters experiencing orgasm.<ref>{{cite book | last = Moore | first = Lisa | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Sperm Counts: Overcome by Man's Most Precious Fluid | publisher = NYU Press | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=tpiyGxq92RwC&dq=Sperm+Counts:+Overcome+by+Man%27s+Most+Precious+Fluid&printsec=frontcover&source=bl&ots=NR_KqeW4hq&sig=UXY6HxT0Wei3ZEeCYZd2H29JWtU&hl=en&ei=LCySSZfdJoi6NM-Z2YkM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result | date = 2007-07-01 | location = NY | pages = 256 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0814757185 }} </ref> However according to the ''[[Village Voice]]'', "The porn phenomenon known as bukkake shoots [[homophobia]] and [[misogyny]] right in the face".<ref name=Routledge/>
==See also== {{Spoken Wikipedia|Narration_-_Bukkake_v4.ogg|2007-02-14}} *[[BDSM]] *[[Cum shot]] *[[Facial (sexuality)|Facial]] *[[Gang bang pornography]] *[[Gokkun]] *[[Group sex]] *[[Seminophagia]] *[[Snowballing (sexual practice)|Snowballing]] *[[Pornography in Japan]]

revision.text:
'''MILF''', an [[acronym]] for "'''mother I'd like to fuck'''", is a common colloquial term generally regarded as vulgar when spelled out. Slight variations include ''mom I'd like to fuck'', or the non-vulgar ''mother I'd like to find'' or ''mother I'd like to fool-around-with''.
==Usage==
MILF denotes a sexually attractive older female, generally between 35 and 50 in age, and not necessarily an actual mother. In the proper use of the term, the female in question should be old enough to be the mother of the person proclaiming her attractiveness. The term was popularized by the film ''[[American Pie (film)|American Pie]] ''(1999),<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.villagevoice.com/2007-10-30/columns/the-rise-of-milfs-and-mommies-in-sexual-fantasy-material/ | title= The Rise of MILFs and Mommies in Sexual-Fantasy Material |last=Taormino |first=Tristan|date=October 30, 2007}}</ref> though the origin of the term predates this (the term was already used for years on the Internet).<ref>[http://groups.google.com/group/alt.mag.playboy/browse_thread/thread/56546dc2e5578c7/ae98e3c554d34114?lnk=st|Usenet_done=%2Fgroup%2Falt.mag.playboy%2Fbrowse_thread%2Fthread%2F56546dc2e5578c7%2Fae98e3c554d34114%3Flnk%3Dst%257CUsenet An example of 1995 internet usage of 'MILF' predating ''American Pie''.]</ref> In addition, the term was used in ''[[Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure]]'' in a description of Bill's stepmom by Ted. In 2007, [[Spirit Airlines]] ran a promotional campaign titled "M.I.L.F.", described as meaning "Many Islands, Low Fares".<ref>{{cite episode |title=Over the Line? |series=The O'Reilly Factor |serieslink=The O'Reilly Factor |network=Fox News Channel |airdate=2007-12-11 |transcripturl=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,316578,00.html}}</ref>
[[Tori Amos]]' song "Big Wheel" on her 2007 album ''American Doll Posse'' refers to herself (or rather the character she portrays in the song) as a MILF.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.hereinmyhead.com/collect/adp/adp02.html | title= Big Wheel lyrics |first=Hereinmyhead.com|date=May 12, 2009}}</ref>

'''Ilan Bunimovitz'''
([[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]]) & ([[Executive director|Director]]) | industry = [[Pornography]] | products = [[DVD]]s, [[Magazines]], [[Licensing]], [[Movies]] & [[Sex toys]] | services = [[Online media]], [[Pay-per-view]], [[Video on Demand]], [[IPTV]], [[Cable television|Cable]] and [[Satellite television]] | market cap = [[United States Dollar|US$]] 79.30 million (''2008'') | revenue = {{decrease}} [[United States Dollar|$]] 19.67 million (''2008'') | operating_income = {{loss}} $ -6.90 million (''2008'') | net_income = {{loss}} $ -5.19 million (''2008'') | assets = {{decrease}} $ 50.86 million (''2008'') | equity = {{decrease}} $ 40.61 million (''2008'') | owner = | num_employees = 123 (''2008'') | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.p-mediagroup.com/ PrivateMediaGroup.com] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Private Media Group, Inc.''' {{NASDAQ|PRVT}} is a [[pornography]] production and distribution company that distributes its content via print publications, DVDs, the internet, and mobile handsets. ''Private'' magazine was established in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]], in 1965 as the world's first full-color [[hardcore pornography|hardcore]] magazine by [[Berth Milton Sr.]] In the early 1990s, his son [[Berth Milton Jr.]] took over and moved the company's headquarters to [[Sant Cugat del Vallès]], [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]], although the company is incorporated in [[Nevada]]. Milton also started to produce movies and internet content, and in 1999, Private became the first [[adult entertainment]] company to be traded on the [[NASDAQ]] stock market. == Product lines == Private releases 10 - 12 new [[DVD]] titles every month and has the largest original content completely [[digital]] adult movie library of over 800 titles.{{Fact|date=March 2009}} Private has multi-lingual websites attracting more than 2.5 million visits with 60 million page views per month.{{Fact|date=March 2009}} Private sites now offers DVD quality movies, [[Video on Demand]] (VOD), [[Internet Protocol Television]] (IPTV), Digital Magazines Download, PSP and iPod downloads. Private supplies pornographic films to thousands of major hotels around the world [[Pay per view|(Hotel Pay Per View)]].{{Fact|date=March 2009}} Private Media Group is a [[Mobile phone|mobile]] content provider for adult entertainment content offering both on-and off portal delivery.{{Fact|date=March 2009}} In August 2008, Private Media Group announced it has established an alliance with [[Marc Dorcel]] to collaborate in the home video market. The collaboration starts with a three year DVD distribution agreement for France and going forward it is expected that Private and [[Marc Dorcel]] will explore additional opportunities in other territories. It is also expected that Private and [[Marc Dorcel]] will join forces on distribution platforms including Internet and IPTV/VOD in both France and across the EU. {{cite web |url=http://www.prvt.com/newsroom/press/view.php?pressid=204 |title=Private Media Group Announces Landmark Strategic Alliance With Marc Dorcel |publisher=prvt.com |accessdate=2009-03-13}} == Movies == ''Private'' is known for high budget adult movies such as the two part series "Millionaire" directed by Alessandro del Mar with a reported budget of $1.9 million.[http://www.avn.com/index.cfm?objectID=ED9FB4FF-1372-4B41-C4B8EB7005383685&slid=130577 Private U.S.A. Sets Release Date For Multimillion-Dollar Feature, Millionaire], AVN Media Network, 3 September 2004 In the last decades, Private Media Group has earned over 130 adult industry awards.{{Fact|date=March 2009}} Bestselling DVD releases include the ''Private Gladiator'' series, ''Cleopatra'', ''Millionaire'' and ''Chateau''. Many actresses made their debut or became famous making movies at Private, including [[Silvia Saint]], [[Tania Russof]], [[Monica Sweetheart]], [[Monique Covét]], [[Laura Angel]], [[Sophie Evans]], [[Dora Venter]], [[Claudia Ferrari]], [[Nikki Anderson]] and [[Angel Dark]].{{Fact|date=March 2009}} ===Awards=== The following is a selection of some of the major awards Private films have won. *1994 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''Private Video Magazine 1'' *1995 AVN award - 'Best Continuing Video Series' for ''Private Video Magazine''{{cite web |url=http://www.avnawards.com/index.php?content=pastwinners |title=AVN AWARDS PAST WINNERS |publisher=[[AVN (magazine)|AVN]] |accessdate=2009-03-13}} *1995 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''Virgin Treasures 1 & 2'' *1996 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''The Tower, Parts 1, 2 & 3'' *1996 AVN award - 'Most Outrageous Sex Scene' for ''Private Video Magazine 20'' *1997 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''The Pyramid, Parts 1, 2 & 3'' *1998 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''The Fugitive 1 & 2'' *1999 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''Tatiana 1, 2 & 3'' *2000 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''Amanda's Diary 2'' *2001 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Vignette Series' for ''Private XXX'' *2003 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''[[Private Gladiator]]'' *2004 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''The Scottish Loveknot'' *2006 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''Robinson Crusoe on Sin Island'' *2007 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''[[Porn Wars|Porn Wars: Episode 1]]'' *2009 AVN award - 'Best [[BDSM]] Release' for ''House of Sex and Domination'' {{cite web |url=http://www.avnawards.com/index.php?content=winners09 |title=THE 2009 AVN AWARDS WINNERS |publisher=[[AVN (magazine)|AVN]] |accessdate=2009-03-07}} *2009 AVN award - 'Best Foreign Feature' for ''Jason Colt, Mystery of the Sexy Diamonds'' ==Management team== Berth H. Milton is the [[Chairman of the board|Chairman]], [[president]], and [[chief executive officer]] Milton was appointed to the Board of Directors of Private Media Group, Inc. in February 1998 and was the Corporate [[Secretary]] from June 1998 until February 1999. In February 1999 Mr. Milton was appointed Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Milton has been [[Administration (business)|Administrator]] of Milcap Media Group from its inception until June 2000 and has been acting as an advisor to Milcap Media Group since 1991. In 2008, as a result of Company’s continuing transition from traditional to digital content distribution, DVD & Magazine sales are decreasing, offset by increased Internet, [[wireless]] and broadcasting sales. Milton expects Internet, [[wireless]] and broadcasting sales to increase significantly, given the rapid growth of these platforms.{{Fact|date=March 2009}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.p-mediagroup.com Private Media Group official website] *[http://www.prvt.com Private Media Group corporate website] *[http://www.sec.gov/cgi-bin/browse-edgar?action=getcompany&CIK=0001068084&owner=include Private Media Group securities filings] [[Category:Companies of Spain]] [[Category:Companies listed on NASDAQ]] [[Category:Adult magazine publishing companies]] [[Category:Pornographic film studios]] [[Category:Adult entertainment companies]] [[Category:Companies based in Catalonia]] [[ca:Private Media Group]] [[de:Private Media Group]] [[es:Private Media Group]] [[fr:Private Media Group]] [[it:Private Media Group]] [[nl:Private Media Group]] [[pt:Private Media Group]] [[sv:Private Media Group]]

[[File:Beate Uhse Hamburger Straße2.jpg|thumb|Beate Uhse shop]]
'''Beate Uhse AG''' is a [[Germany|German]] [[Sex industry|industry group]] with focus on selling adult entertainment in the form of [[sex toy]]s, [[lingerie]], [[clothing]] and [[pornography]]. It is the most successful company in the German [[sex industry]],<ref name=Flying/> and the countries leading pornography retailer.<ref name=Glatzer>{{cite book|title=Recent social trends in West Germany, 1960-1990|publisher=[[McGill-Queen's Press]]|author=Wolfgang Glatzer |year=1992|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=liMU3HPW99oC|isbn=3593344025|page=429}}</ref> It was founded by former German [[World War II|war-time]] pilot and sex pioneer [[Beate Uhse-Rotermund]]<ref name=Flying>{{cite book|title=Flying for her country: the American and Soviet women military pilots of World War II|publisher=[[Greenwood Publishing Group]]|author=Amy Goodpaster Strebe, Trish Beckman |year=2007|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=bFbUVQNeSwoC|isbn=0275994341|page=3}}</ref> in [[1946]] and started out as a distibutor of [[pamphlet|pamphlets]] on [[family planning]] called ''Schrift X'' (roughly: ''Writing X'' or ''Paper X'') which was a major success. In [[1962]] the company opened the world's first [[sex shop]] in [[Flensburg]].<ref name=Flying/> When [[pornography]] was finally made legal in [[West Germany]] in [[1976]], Beate Uhse was well-prepared with a widely known and respected [[Brand|brand name]] and an established [[mail order]] business. By 1992 it owned 30 sex shops and 25 cinemas, had a turnover of 100 million Deutschmarks, and 10 million customers visited its premises.<ref name=Glatzer/> It currently has over 1,500 [[employee]]s, is active in 60 [[country|countries]] and has been listed on the [[Frankfurt Stock Exchange]] since [[1999]]. Uhse remained the chairwoman of the company until her death in 2001.<ref name=Flying/> In [[2004]] Beate Uhse AG opened the first Mae B. [[Retailing|shop]], a chain of [[sex shop]]s specifically aimed at [[female]] [[consumer]]s. In [[2004]] the combined [[sales]] of the Beate Uhse industry group was €280 million, making it the largest [[Distribution (business)|distributor]] of [[Sex industry|adult-related entertainment]] and [[Product (business)|products]] in the [[world]]. [[Profit (accounting)|Profits]] have dropped significantly in the year [[2006]] - [[2007]].<ref>http://www.fmwf.com/newsarticle.php?id=1374&cat=5, Financial Mail Women's Forum, [[26 August]] [[2007]]</ref> A Beate Uhse employee Michael Vaughan <ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/2372027.stm ,BBC News, [[30 October]] [[2002]]</ref><ref>http://business.guardian.co.uk/story/0,3604,822245,00.html ,The Guardian, [[30 October]] [[2002]]</ref> and former [[Ann Summers]] director was pursuing a [[Defamation|libel claim]] against [[Jacqueline Gold]]<ref>[http://www.pressdisplay.com/pressdisplay/viewer.aspx?issue=13002007091600000000001001&page=8&article=cc897791-4557-4506-8451-2dc4385745e6&key=Xp7m6GUcZW3qiK+3JssRFA==&feed=rss PressDisplay.com - Newspapers From Around the World<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.beateuhse.ag/index.html Beate Uhse AG official homepage] *[http://www.pabo.com/ Beate Uhse adult products website]

{{Cleanup|date=February 2008}}
'''Jan Novak''' is a Czech director and producer of [[gay pornography|gay pornographic films]].
==Career== Novak's career began while shooting with his camera as a hobby, and befriended William Higgins in the early 1990s. Novak soon opened a [[Gay bar|gay club]] in [[Prague]], followed by a gay sex shop and mail order business - and then he began publishing his first gay erotic magazines in the [[Czech Republic]].
Soon, a friend convinced him to create his own photo production company, and Lukas Studios was born to give Novak's photography an outlet. His work caught the eye of Higgins's friend, George Mavety - owner of Mavety Media Group. Novak saw his pictures in the pages of ''[[Playguy]]'', ''[[Honcho]]'', ''[[Torso]]'', ''[[Mandate magazine|Mandate]]'', and ''Inches''.
Novak initially resisted offers to produce videos... until the day he got a fax from [[Studio 2000]] producers John Travis and [[Scott Masters]], who asked him to come to the United States.
He was nominated for a [[GayVN Awards|GayVN Award]] and won a [[Grabby]] (''Winning Ways'' took the 2001 award for Best International Video[http://www.media-imdb.com/Sections/Awards/Grabby_Awards/2001]), and he continued working with Studio 2000 for two years to develop its international line with titles like ''Good and Bad'', ''Strokes to Seduction'', ''Criminal Intent'', and ''The Back Room''. Novak's photography experience helped him compose films and he was hired as managing director of Bel Ami Prague office when his Studio 2000 stint was up.
In the spring of 2004, Novak left [[Bel Ami (adult film company)|Bel Ami]] and established Bubble B Entertainment, with ''Alluring Cumback'' its first release. [http://www.avn.com/index.cfm?objectID=F7836D5E-0710-850B-A8062829C04032E2&slid=387774]
==Selected Films== *''BoyHunt'' (2007) (director, producer) *''Night Eyes'' (2006) (director, producer) *''Alluring Cumback'' (2005) (director, producer) *''Winning Ways'' (2000) (director, producer) *''The Backroom'' (2000) (director, producer, writer) *''Payload'' (1999) (director, cinematographer)

{{AfDM|page=Gwen Media|logdate=2009 September 19|substed=yes}} {{Orphan|date=February 2009}} {{Infobox_Company | company_name = Gwen Media | company_logo = [[File:Gwen Media logo.jpg|275px]] company_type = Private | company_slogan = ''Finest in Fetish Entertainment'' | foundation = [[1999]] | key_people = [[Isabella Sinclaire]], Owner (Current)
Founders
[[Robert "Bob" Zak]], Founder (deceased)
[[John Fitzgerald (Thndrshark)]], Founder | homepage = [http://www.gwenmedia.com/ www.gwenmedia.com] }} '''Gwen Media''' is an adult film company based in California, United States which produces mostly BDSM photographs and occasional films. The current company is a successor to the original film company, using the same name and same commercial website url. The current company produces mainly "adult only" photographs and occasional DVD films unlike the original company which mostly produced films. This new company is owned by notable BDSM performer and dominatrix, Isabella Sinclaire, who was one of the primary performers of the original company. == Background == The original Gwen Media film company (formally known as "Gwenmedia Los Angeles") was a Los Angeles, California based film company that concentrated in creating Latex and BDSM focused adult films (usually considered "pornographic" due to the usage of many specific "adult only" themes in their films which included BDSM, heavy bondage, implied sci-fi bodily conversions and full frontal nudity. Gwen Media did NOT use female-to-female sex, except in a few of their produced films, such as "Fetish Girls". There was NO male-to-female sex in any of the original Gwen Media films that were publicly released). The original Gwen Media was originally formed by Bob Zak and John Fitzgerald (see Thndrshark.com) as an outgrowth of Zak's fetish clothing business, "Whiplash USA".[http://web.archive.org/web/20020404013626/whiplashusa.com/septindex.php] Fitzgerald served as Gwen Media's original film director and primary screen writer until he left the original company in 2002.[http://www.avn.com/index.php?Primary_Navigation=Articles&Action=View_Article&Content_ID=276134] Fitzgerald was ultimately replaced by Jon White as primary film director of the original company. Jon White would later succeed Bob Zak as the Managing Producer of the company after Zak died in June 2005.[http://www.avn.com/index.php?Primary_Navigation=Articles&Action=View_Article&Content_ID=231947] The original Gwen Media had been primarily producing adult films from late (generally considered September) 1999 until the then recognized management, led by Jon White, officially ended production of the original company in March 2006.[http://www.lustlovelatex.com/2006/03/gwenmedia-is-closing-down.htm] In the beginning, the original Gwen Media produced only a few high-end production films a year due to their elaborate settings and production values which prevented "factory mass production".[http://web.archive.org/web/20001017173049/www.gwenmedia.com/Videos.htm] It would be these elaborate settings and emotional convincing performers that established Gwen Media as the premier fetish adult film company in the United States, surpassing the few United States specific fetish companies such as California Star and HOM Studios as well as the occasion film productions from outside the United States including notable long-time fetish producers [[Peter W. Czernich]] ''[[Marquis (magazine)]]'' of Germany and ''[[Skin Two]]'' of England. Gwen Media developed a core audience and devoted fan following that allowed Gwen Media to increase their film production level to a regular production amount of approximately 4 films EACH MONTH of varying time lengths (45 min – 120 min) near the end of the original company's production life cycle in 2006, culminating in over 110 known released DVD movies. The original Gwen Media's high success was largely attributed to a definite and continual focus by Zak and the production staff on using their successful fundamental basis of specific BDSM performers, elaborate sets and locales, definite scripts and high-end latex costuming in all their film productions. Zak did not even offer photogalleries on the website until 2001, leaving the site only as a commercial re-sales site for the films.[http://web.archive.org/web/20001109173600/www.gwenmedia.com/Videos.htm] Photography was almost exclusively used as promotional material for the films and "test-out" of audience interest to proposed film sessions and focuses. It was this continual focus as a specific fetish film company that used direct audience feedback that contributed to the original company's success where other BDSM film makers had NOT gained a reliable footing into the adult market such as those produced by known BDSM specific adult film production companies including Rick Savage (Noose Videos)[http://www.iafd.com/person.rme/perfid=RSavage/gender=m/Rick-Savage.htm], the late Bruce Sevens[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0786249/] and Bizarre Videos[http://www.bizarrevideo.com/]. The original Gwen Media would later form a distribution partnership with Bizarre Videos for their films.[http://www.avn.com/index.php?Primary_Navigation=Articles&Action=View_Article&Content_ID=231947] While many had thought the usage of definite scripts and elaborate plots and extensive full-body latex costuming would limit the "porn" audience for these films, it was those very factors that had developed the definite audience following of latex fetish fans who had very little specific fetish film product to select from and from more "vanilla" adult fans who wanted something more elaborate than the general offerings from generic adult film makers. Through the course of their initial development, Gwen Media widely promoted many of their initial performers including Isabella Sinclaire (current owner of succeeding company), [[Jewell Marceau]], [[Emily Marilyn]] (aka Molly Matthews), [[Eden Wells]], Anastasia Pierce and [[Paige Richards]], as well as several of their later performers including Amanda Wildefyre, (Mistress) Aradia, and of course, Jean Bardot who has found large-scale acceptance in the fetish market in her role as "Rubberella".[http://ainews.com/Archives/Story6638.phtml] The original Gwen Media's most successful products were their various continual high-end production film series, including "Part-time"; "Ivy Manor" (episode 5 entitled "Teacher's Pet" won 2003 AVN Best BDSM film,[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AVN_Awards_2003] gathering large-scale adult film recognition for this "niche" fetish film company); "Sessions" (episode 8 was nominated for 2004 AVN Best BDSM film)[http://www.avnawards.com]; "Crimson Mansion"[http://ainews.com/Archives/Story5504.phtml] and "Rubberella". == Legal Dispute ends original company == The Gwen Media web site (www.gwenmedia.com) was closed in June 2006 with the front page displaying the message ''“Account for domain gwenmedia.com has been suspended”'' . This unclear statement was posted after a public announcement was made in March 2006 by the succeeding management to actually end all productions of the company after the death of company owner and founder, Bob Zak, in June 2005 from heart failure.[http://www.avn.com/index.php?Primary_Navigation=Articles&Action=View_Article&Content_ID=231947] The announcement was met with curiosity as it was assumed that the company had completely ended with the public statement in March 2006, and the site would be completely removed rather than being merely "suspended". The PUBLIC reason for this "suspension" was revealed in September 2006 to have been a legal dispute between one-time lead performer Isabella Sinclaire and company owner and producer, Bob Zak. http://www.avn.com/index.php?Primary_Navigation=Articles&Action=View_Article&Content_ID=276134 The case was based on ownership of key products of Gwen Media's production company, most notably the "Ivy Manor" film line which was considered the basis for the company's initial financial success and allowed Gwen Media to prosper and build up the company from that initial successful money generation. Sinclaire was the main star of this Gwen Media film series. Sinclaire stated that she owned the name of the series which was based on her company's incorporated name. This challenge was disputed by Bob Zak who argued that the film series was their property. In September 2006, the legal ownership case of the "Ivy Manor" series was determined in Sinclaire's favor. In order to compensate Sinclaire for her legal fees, the judge in the case awarded Sinclaire complete ownership of Gwen Media and all its assets including all of the films. This award was not limited to only the "Ivy Manor" series, but included all of Gwen Media's trademarks, photostock and properties. == New company and Recent Events == After being awarded full legal ownership of the original company,[http://www.avn.com/index.php?Primary_Navigation=Articles&Action=View_Article&Content_ID=276134] Sinclaire has announced publicly that she intends to reactivate Gwen Media as a fully separate, though completely owned, company parallel to her original adult film company, "Ivy Manor Videos". Sinclaire continues to operate and produce for her own original adult film company "Ivy Manor Videos" at this time. Sinclaire has reactivated Gwen Media as an active production company as of February 14, 2007, after placing her re-activication notice on the Gwen Media website on December 12, 2006. Though awarded of all Gwen Media's trademarks, products, and resources, Sinclaire has made no indication that she would reactivate other Gwen Media associated companies at this time such as "Crimson Mansion" or "American Pinups". `Originally, such websites were "suspended".[http://www.crimsonmansion.com] These supplementary companies and subsidiaries of the original company have been sold/released as of October 2008 and are no longer part of Gwen Media. Sinclaire has not stated publicly whether she will rehire any of the former management of Zak's incarnation of the company for her incarnation of Gwen Media. Sinclaire DID state publicly that she was in negotiations to work with co-founder John Fitzgerald to write new stories for her incarnation of Gwen Media.[http://www.avn.com/index.php?Primary_Navigation=Articles&Action=View_Article&Content_ID=276134] According to the report, Sinclaire stated she had "contacted John Fitzgerald and we will be continuing the Ivy Manor series until we complete the 10-part series as planned". Sinclaire has stated in her first public press release for her incarnation of Gwen Media (dated February 14, 2007) that their association is a permanent one as Fitzgerald has been hired as creative producer and primary film director for the successive company[http://www.gwenmedia.com/news.html]. Sinclaire has not stated publicly whether she will continue to follow the latex fetish focus of Bob Zak's production or change to her own noted BDSM style which does not use latex fetish as the primary focus either at this time. However based on some of the initial photo productions that have been publicly released, it seems that she will maintain the latex sci-fi focus at least for the initial time. == Possible future legal dispute == There is a quiet contention at this time that the famous "Rubberella" character, primarily portrayed by noted fetish performer Jean Bardot, is also now part of Isabella Sinclaire's Gwen Media. The Rubberella character was originally created by Zak and Bardot to be marketed specifically as part of Gwen Media.[http://ainews.com/Archives/Story5942.phtml] Bardot has stated that she was awarded control of the property by former manager Jon White before White ended the company in March 2006. But the judge who awarded Sinclaire control over all Gwen Media assets and trademarks did not state an exclusion for this character. Thus Sinclaire could restart Rubberella as well as any of the other original series with completely new performers, akin to the ''[[James Bond]]'' film franchise where many different actors have portrayed the same character. What is known is that Bardot has stated that she does NOT have legal rights to re-release any of the seven films that she portrayed the Rubberella character for Zak's Gwen Media which was awarded and transferred to Sinclaire's ownership. Many believe that Sinclaire and Bardot are quietly trying to come to an agreement on the matter without having to bring any legal contention to the matter as to the rights of the creator (Bardot) versus that of the producer (Sinclaire). Recently both the new Gwen Media and Jean Bardot's Rubberella websites have celebrated the return of Gwen Media with photoshoots featuring Sinclaire and Bardot together. The series on the Rubberella site (entitled "Exam Room") includes Sinclaire giving Bardot a kiss which leave a large lipstick mark, which remains in subsequent photos in the series. This kiss suggests that the two have come to some public agreement involving the Rubberella character (having "kissed and made up"). While this initial public promotion campaign capitalizes on the success of one of the most successful of the former Gwen Media products, neither Bardot nor Sinclaire have stated whether they will continue to work together at this time beyond this initial public promotion campaign. === New Gwenmedia ends Classic Rubberella === On Friday, July 6, 2007, a message was posted on the "Rubberella" website formally stating that there was an ending of Jean Bardot's association with the character :"-MEMBERS- :Jean Bardot is no longer Rubberella !! www.Rubberella.com as you know it will no longer, in anyway, be associated to or with Jean Bardot." This message obviously indicates that Isabella is indeed the controller of the character and will continue to use the character as part of her new Gwen Media in future projects. At the current time, it is unclear who will succeed Jean in the role of Rubberella if the series is to be restarted at all. There was no listing of the reason of the ending of Jean's involvement with the character nor if the ending was an amicable one, nor if Jean will continue to work with Gwen Media in other roles than this one. On Monday, July 16, 2007, the Rubberella.com website was suspended by Gwenmedia management. As of November 2008, there has been no formal word from management on any possible restart of this series at some undefined later time. === New Gwenmedia formally restarts "Ivy Manor" series === Gwenmedia has announced that its original series "Ivy Manor" will be available for public screening on Wednesday, November 28, 2007. This restart of the series marks the formal restart of the film production of the original production series of Gwenmedia. The new film "Ivy Manor 5: Rubber Dreams" is a re-imagining of the original AVN award winning version "Ivy Manor 5: Teacher's Pet" as if the original series storyline had been continued by John Fitzgerald. The recent film entitled "Ivy Manor Slaves" released by the new Gwenmedia was not part of this series, despite having the same story writer/director (John Fitzgerald) and primary performer (Jewell Marceau). === AVN Awards === On November 25, 2007, the AVN Awards committee announced that "Ivy Manor Slaves" was nominated for "2008 AVN Awards Best Speciality film-BDSM".[http://www.avnawards.com/pdf/2008Nominations.pdf] This film did not win the category. The winner was "House of Sex and Domination" from Private The formal Ivy Manor Gwen Media series was also nominated for "2009 AVN Awards Best Speciality series". This series did not win. The winner was "Taboo" from Hustler. === Jean Bardot starts own production === With a new public announcement made on November 14, 2007, Jean Bardot has stated she is completely separate from Gwenmedia and will begin releasing her own films from her own production company. While Jean is a directly competiting producer to Gwenmedia now, several other performers who work with Gwenmedia also release their own film products separate from Gwenmedia though in the same fetish idea, including Jewell Marceau and Anastasia Pierce. Thus it remains to be seen if Jean will work with Gwenmedia in the future. It should be noted that Batdot's picture has remained on the entry page of the website during the entire removal of Bardot from the Rubberella character, and afterwards. In fact Bardot image remains as the initial "face" of the Gwen Media website as of June 2009. === Sinclaire announced she is closing Gwen Media === On November 14, 2008, Isabella posted an announcement on her public website that she intends to end her dominatrix career to "pursue other avenues" which remain unspecified.[http://www.dominationonline.com/newsletter/Oct08/IVYnewsOct08.html] In line with her on-screen persona as a dominatrix, Sinclaire has stated she is ending her online websites and both Ivy Manor Videos and Gwen Media. In August 2009, Sinclaire stated she is leaving her established base in Los Angeles.[http://www.isabellasinclaire.com/blog/static.php?page=static090306-214702] It was not stated if she sold her Los Angeles studios. Sinclaire has not clearly stated if she merely will end Gwen Media or sell it off to someone else to continue. As of August 2009, there has been no recant from Sinclaire on her publicly stated decision to end her webcompanies' production. However, Sinclaire has yet to announce a specified date of closure either. Thus it remains unclear what will be Gwen Media's last day of operation. == References == {{cite news |last=Stanton |first=Thomas J. |url=http://www.avn.com/index.php?Primary_Navigation=Articles&Action=View_Article&Content_ID=276134 |title=Mistress Isabella Awarded Ownership of GwenMedia |publisher=AVN News |date=2006-09-22 |accessdate=2006-11-07}} {{cite news |last=Ramone |first=Mike |url=http://www.avn.com/index.php?Primary_Navigation=Articles&Action=View_Article&Content_ID=231947 |title=GwenMedia Owner Bob Zak Passes Away |publisher=AVN News |date=2005-06-28 |accessdate=2006-11-07}} {{cite news |last=White |first=Jon |url=http://ainews.com/Archives/Story6638.phtml |title=GwenMedia Releases Rubberella 3 |publisher=AINews |date=2004-04-23 |accessdate=2005-10-27}} {{cite news |last=Zak |first=Bob |url=http://ainews.com/Archives/Story5942.phtml |title=Announcing Rubberella Sub-Site |publisher=AINews |date=2003-12-09 |accessdate=2005-11-07}} {{cite news |url=http://www.lustlovelatex.com/2006/03/gwenmedia-is-closing-down.htm |title=Gwenmedia is Closing Down! |publisher=3xl |date=2006-03-07 |accessdate=2005-11-07}} == See also == *[[Agalmatophilia]] *[[BDSM]] *[[Bondage (BDSM)]] *[[Latex and PVC fetishism]] *[[Latex clothing|Latex]] *[[Total enclosure]] *[[Sexual fetishism|Fetish]] *[[Human animal roleplay]] "ponyplay" *[[Erotic objectification]] == External links == *[http://www.gwenmedia.com Gwenmedia.com] Official site (Adult Content) *[http://www.isabellasinclaire.com Isabella Sinclaire's public website] (Adult Content) [[Category:Adult entertainment companies]] [[Category:Pornographic film studios]] [[Category:Film production companies of the United States]] [[Category:Media companies of the United States]] [[Category:BDSM in films]] [[Category:Companies established in 1999]]

'''Mystique Magazine''' is an Austin, TX based glamour company, founded in 1998. The company features “women you could spend the rest of your life with."
Most of its photo shoots and productions are done in exotic locations. The photos, most of them shot by Mark Daughn, are more about creating a mood or a feeling in an image, and not about how explicit or revealing it can be. The company features a variety of models. There is no “cookie-cutter” formula. Some popular well known models featured in Mystique include [[Linda O'Neil]], [[Erica Campbell]], [[Aria Giovanni]] and [[Sunny Leone]]. Some of the company's own popular discoveries include [[Katia Corriveau]], [[Aurora Vaillantcourt]] and [[Deanna Merryman]].
Mystique Magazine publishes hardcover coffee-table books, a web site, and a range DVDs and wall calendars. In 2004, the company also began producing original television programming for North America’s top Pay Per View networks, such as [[inDemand]] and [[Dish Network]].

{{Infobox Company | company_name = Kink.com | company_logo = <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:kink-logo red 1.jpg|150px]] --> | company_type = Private | foundation = [[1997]] | location = {{flagicon|United States}} [[San Francisco, California]], [[United States]] | industry = [[Pornography]] | products = [[Pornographic film]]s, [[internet pornography]] and [[sex toys|sex toys]] | homepage = [http://www.kink.com/ Kink.com] }}
'''Kink.com''' is a [[San Francisco]]-based [[internet pornography]] company that runs a group of [[websites]] devoted to [[BDSM]] and related [[Sexual fetishism|fetishes]].
==Hogtied.com== Kink.com was started by UK-native [[Peter Acworth]] in 1997 while he was a PhD student in [[finance]] at [[Columbia University]]. After reading a story in a British [[tabloid]] about a fireman who made 250 thousand [[pound sterling|pounds]] in a short period by starting an internet pornography site, Acworth decided to start a porn site of his own. Since Acworth had what he described as a lifelong interest in bondage, he oriented the site toward BDSM porn.<ref name=Mooallem> [http://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/29/magazine/29kink.t.html "A Disciplined Business"] by Jon Mooallem, ''[[The New York Times Magazine]],'' April 29, 2007.</ref> The site was called Hogtied.com and initially featured content that was licensed from other primary producers. The site was successful, and the site was soon grossing several thousand dollars per day. Acworth soon left his graduate studies to work on the site full time.<ref name=Mooallem/>
==Move to San Francisco== In 1998, Acworth moved the company from [[New York City]] to [[San Francisco]].<ref name=Mooallem/> Finding that sales were leveling off because other sites were using the same content, Acworth began producing his own content, initially featuring himself with various models who he found through [[Craigslist]] or through his photographer friends.<ref name=Mooallem/><ref>[http://www.7x7sf.com/people/profiles/3545792.html "The New Pornographers"] by Robin Rinaldi, ''7x7'', August 01, 2006.</ref> He opened the company's second site, [[Fucking machines|Fucking Machines]], in 2000,<ref name=VillageVoice>[http://www.villagevoice.com/2008-07-16/columns/the-man-behind-the-fucking-machine/" The Man Behind the Fucking Machines"], ''[[Village Voice]],'' July 16, 2008</ref>. and has since opened fourteen additional subscription websites.<ref>[http://news.behindkink.com/blog/default/2008/02/01/Kink-com-Celebrates-its-10-year-Anniversary "Kink.com Celebrates its 10 Year Anniversary"], ''Behind Kink'', February 1, 2008.</ref>
Several websites under the '''Kink.com''' umbrella feature directors that relocated following the demise of [[Insex]] as a result of US government pressure in 2005, but offer more of a focus on consensuality than Insex was known for.
In late 2006, Kink.com purchased the [[San Francisco Armory]] for $14.5 million, for use as a production studio. A group known as the Mission Armory Community Collective formed to oppose Kink.com's use of the building and in early February 2007 held a public protest in front of the building.<ref name="Mooallem" /><ref name=guardian> [http://www.sfbg.com/entry.php?entry_d=3027&catid=4 "Kink hearing: The pornographer's purchase of the Armory faces more roadblocks"] by Deborah Giattina, ''[[San Francisco Bay Guardian]]'', March 7, 2007.</ref> Some residents of the [[Mission District]] were disturbed by Kink.com's purchase of the [[San Francisco Armory]], feeling that a pornography studio should not be located in the middle of a residential neighborhood near schools or that the site should have been used for low-income housing or other community-oriented uses.<ref name=guardian> [http://www.sfbg.com/entry.php?entry_id=3027&catid=4 "Kink hearing: The pornographer's purchase of the Armory faces more roadblocks"] by Deborah Giattina, ''[[San Francisco Bay Guardian]]'', March 7, 2007.</ref><ref name="lagos"/><ref name=sfgtv/><ref> [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2007/02/02/national/a105718S92.DTL "Porn Studio Puts City in a Kink"] by Lisa Leff, ''San Francisco Chronicle'', February 2, 2007</ref> At one point, there were plans to destroy part of the structure to accommodate condominium development. Ironically, the condo plan's changing of the integrity of the building created supporters who welcomed Kink.com's use of The Armory as a way of revitalizing the structure and bringing back business to the area without altering the appearance of the historic building, as well as being in keeping with San Francisco's tradition of accommodating [[sexual minorities]].<ref name=sfgtv> [http://sanfrancisco.granicus.com/MediaPlayer.php?view_id=20&clip_id=3256 "San Francisco Planning Commission - Special Public Hearing"], ''SFGTV'', March 8, 2007. (link to streaming [[Windows Media]] video and downloadable [[MP3]] audio)</ref> San Francisco mayor [[Gavin Newsom]] also expressed concern over the Kink.com purchase, and scheduled a special meeting of the San Francisco Planning Commission in March 2007 to review the company's use of the building.<ref name="Mooallem" /> The meeting was well-attended by both supporters and detractors of the Kink.com purchase. The Planning Commission for its part ruled that Kink.com was not in violation of any law or [[zoning]] requirement.<ref name=bar> [http://www.ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=1648 "Planning Commission hears Kink.com case"] by Liz Highleyman, ''[[Bay Area Reporter]]'', March 15, 2007.</ref><ref name=chronicle1>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/01/13/BAG0INI8PD1.DTL|title=Ex-armory turns into porn site|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|date=2007-01-13}}</ref><ref name=lagos>[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/01/26/BAG5RNPKIV1.DTL No welcome mat for adult film studio"] by Marisa Lagos, ''San Francisco Chronicle'', January 26, 2007</ref> Although Kink.com has stated that its activities would be invisible to the surrounding neighborhood, La Casa de las Madres, a neighboring [[women's shelter]], announced that they would be leaving the location because of the media scrutiny of Kink.com's presence.<ref> [http://sanfrancisco.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2007/03/26/story12.html| "Service organization flees from kinky Mission neighbor"] by Sarah Duxbury, ''San Francisco Business Times'', March 23, 2007.</ref>
In 2007, the company's website [[Fucking machines|Fucking Machines]] was involved in a [[trademark]] dispute when the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] refused to grant a trademark for the name of the site, asserting that it was obscene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orlandoweekly.com/features/story.asp?id=11596|title=THE F BOMB |last=Jeffrey C. Billman|date=2007-06-07|work=Orlando Weekly|accessdate=2008-09-09}}</ref>
==Online streaming== In 2007, the company began streaming regular live shows, in part as a defense against [[copyright infringement]].<ref> [http://news.cnet.com/2100-1026_3-6172180.html "At Kink.com, A Live Tool Against Piracy"], ''CNet News'', March 30, 2007.</ref> One Kink.com bondage site, Device Bondage, now streams monthly live shows,<ref> [http://www.xbiz.com/news/news_piece.php?id=97914 "Trina Michaels to Appear Live on DeviceBondage.com"], ''XBiz'', August 14, 2008.</ref> and erotic wrestling site Ultimate Surrender began streaming its competitive matches live in 2008.<ref> [http://avn.com/internet/articles/31837.html "Ultimate Surrender Streams 3 Matches Live"], ''Adult Video News'', August 18, 2008.</ref>
In 2008, the company added on-demand technology to its websites, selling updates to their websites on a per-episode basis rather than strictly by subscription.<ref> [http://www.avn.com/internet/articles/31643.html "Kink.com Launches Kink On Demand"], ''Adult Video News'', August 6, 2008.</ref> This system recently began adding third-party content, including that from Germany's [[Marquis (magazine)|Marquis]].<ref> [http://avn.com/internet/articles/31860.html "Kink.com Partners With Germany's Marquis"], ''Adult Video News'', August 19, 2008.</ref> The company's most recently launched site is BoundGods.com, a gay bondage site directed by [[Van Darkholme]]. Bound Gods was launched under a new gay-focused division, KinkMen.com.<ref> [http://www.avn.com/gay/articles/31575.html "Kink.com Launches First Gay Bondage Site"], ''Adult Video News'', August 4, 2008.</ref>
In November, 2008, Kink.com was nominated for a 2009 AVN Award in a new category, Best Adult Website.<ref> [http://avnawards.com/pdf/2009_AVN_NOMINATIONS_11_25_08.pdf "Complete 2009 AVN Awards Nominee List"], ''AVNAwards.com'', November 25, 2008.</ref>
